videos.title: Kids Science: Soap Powered Boat
videos.description:
Here is our soap powered boat that Alex has made from a business card. He cut corners of the card and put soap at the back of the boat. After he placed the boat onto the water, it scooted across. To try that again, we needed to rinse out the tray to remove any soap and add fresh water. Soap breaks down the surface tension of water.  As the surface tension is broken up, it creates enough of a force to push our boat across the surface
=====================================================

videos.title: Mermaid Pillow Sensory Activity For Kids
videos.description:
Mermaid Pillows are made from small sequins with different colours on the front and at the back. When children move their fingers through the fabric they flip sequins over changing its colour. It is perfect for a sensory activity, but you can also reinforce top-to-bottom writing for only a few letters that don't have horizontal or curved lines in them. I put a piece of a cardboard inside the pillowcase to make it easier for children to play with. Mermaid pillows are not that expensive and there are different combinations of colours for any taste. videos.title: How To Suck A Water Balloon Into A Bottle
videos.description:
Alex tried to put filled with water balloon inside the jar, but he couldn't. So we heated the air inside the jar and it expanded. Once we put the water balloon on top it, the flame went out and the air in the jar started cooling and shrinking back to its old size. But the balloon didn't let any more air into the bottle and it got sucked in.
Before doing this experiment we talked about the danger of fire and that only an adult should handle it.  
=====================================================

videos.title: How To Make Drawings Float With A Magic Water Marker
videos.description:
Subscribe to my channel and wait for Alex’s space adventure floating drawing! To make your art creation float you need just white board makers, a plate and some water. I have seen a few videos about this technique but they all seemed to require to much and didn't promise result. So here is the ultimate guide to make your drawings float. First you need regular fresh dry erase markers. Old ones usually do not work. Just test your magic water markers before you do the activity. Draw a circle with each marker on a plate, pour some water and if the circle floats, you are ready to go. You can use a piece of glass or laminated sheet, however I recommend using a regular plate. When you draw something, make sure you are colouring all the bits inside of the drawing, to make sure the drawing is strong enough to float. Blow to make your drawings move 
=====================================================

videos.title: How To Make A Glass Object Disappear: Kids Science Experiment
videos.description:
Don't trust your eyes! If you cannot see it, it doesn't mean that it is not there. When you place a Pyrex stir rod in the vegetable oil, it disappears. The secret here is that vegetable oil has nearly the same index of refraction as Pyrex glass

videos.title: The Tower of Hanoi - Kids Activities
videos.description:
We used this stacker with three rods to play Towers of Hanoi. The rules of the game are quite simple. At the start, all the disks are on one side, with the largest disk on the bottom and the smallest on the top. The object of the game is to move all the disks over to the other side. You can only move one disk per move, and you can only move the top disk on a stack. Disks can only be moved to empty stacks or on top of larger disks. Parents can play this game too, just add extra discs.
Get your stacker here http://geni.us/stacker

videos.title: How to Make a Chemical Traffic Light | Kids Science
videos.description:
How fun is this chemical traffic light experiment!? Liquid changes colour from green to red and later to yellow. The best part is it is repeatable. Just shake the bottle to start again.
Ok. That is maybe not the kind of experiment you have ingredients in your kitchen for, but it’s definitely worth getting them. For this experiment you would need:
- Dye called indigo carmine 0.05g
- Caustic soda (Sodium hydroxide) 2.5g
- Glucose (dextrose) 1.5g
- Water 125 ml
If the colours stop changing, just open the bottle for more oxygen to get inside and add a bit more of indigo carmine 
=====================================================

videos.title: How to Make a Tornado in a Bottle
videos.description:
It’s an experiment time! We have connected two bottles with a tube (we got it from here http://geni.us/tornado) but you can just connect them with a tape, just make sure you put a metal washer between bottles to make the hole smaller. Spinning the top bottle in a circular motion creates a water vortex that looks like a tornado. They say that you can colour water, add dish soap, glitter or lamp oil to make this experiment more impressive, but I find that using clear water works the best.
=====================================================

videos.title: How To Touch The Air - Kids Science | AD
videos.description:
This video contains paid for advertorial.
We breathe in around 10,000 litres of air a day, but the fact that I live in a city means that the air quality is not very good. Children breathe in more air than adults, meaning air pollution affects them more. Indoor air can be up to 5 times more polluted and even so we often spend time in nature, we do return home at the end. After switching our @Philips Air Purifier on [http://philips.to/2u7WES9] for the first time, it tested the air and quickly removed dust, pollen and even viruses in the room. Since then we have been enjoying beautifully clean air and talking about it a lot. Today we have done a simple science experiment allowing Alex to touch the air. How clean is the air where you are?
#Sponsored #TheDadLab #BreatheTheDifference #London

videos.title: How to Make a Lemon Battery
videos.description:
When you run out of batteries, but you have a few lemons at home. To start, we put copper coins and galvanized nails on different sides of lemons. Then we connected the nail to the copper coin on the next lemon in a line with a wire. After connecting red wire (representing "+") to the coin on the first lemon and black wire (representing "-") to the nail of the last lemon, it was time to test the power. It made Alex really happy to see how LED lighted up and the buzzer started making a sound with a power of just a few lemons.
Keep in mind that in this experiment electricity comes not from a lemon but from Zinc on galvanised nails, so you, in fact, can use just one lemon and put a few nails and coins there to get the same results. I used a few lemons to make it more visual for Alex
=====================================================

videos.title: How To Make Dinosaur Ice Eggs
videos.description:
It was a challenge to put our big dinosaurs inside balloons, but I did it and managed to make frozen dino eggs after all. I guess we could use warm water and salt to help our dinosaurs to hatch, but using hummers is much more fun! I intentionally did not add food colouring to our eggs to avoid stains on clothing. If you are up to hammering some ice eggs, make sure you wear glasses for protection!

videos.title: Funnel Fun Experiment
videos.description:
This is fun funnel experiment that proves that an empty bottle isn't, in fact, empty and to fill it with water we need to make sure that air can escape. If a funnel is properly sealed to a bottle and a lot of water is poured into it at once, water should just stay in there and not go through to bottle. In our case, play-dough didn't make the seal completely air-proof (vortex in a funnel did not help too), but we had a chance to compare the speed of filling two bottles anyway

videos.title: TodayAtApple Kids Hour: Coding the Droids with TheDadLab | AD
videos.description:
In promotional partnership with Apple. Last week we went to our local Apple store for Kids Hour program where Alex was taught how to code the Droids from Star Wars. First Alex was given an opportunity to familiarize himself with commands that robots can do by playing with them on a table. I should say that one droid went down before Alex got the hang of it. But then Alex built a maze on a floor with a tape and he was taught how to code to make a robot change directions and speed. All in all, we had a great time there and learned something new too.  I want you and your children to have the awesome experience we had. #TodayAtApple isn't only about coding skills, there are programs in music, art, photography, and videography too, they run globally every day and best of all they are free. So visit http://apple.co/todayatapple and find a session in your local Apple store that is right for you.

videos.title: How to Make Raw Chocolate With Kids at Home
videos.description:
A beautiful raw chocolate made by Alex with love! This really simple recipe puts you in control of what chocolate your child tries. You can go all organic on it if you want. You can add anything you like to it: raisins, seeds, nuts... you name it! Whatever ingredients you choose, you will definitely taste the difference comparing to store-bought chocolate. 
Ingredients:
- 1 cup of Coconut Oil (or Raw Cacao Butter)
- 1 cup of Raw Cacao Powder
- 1/2 cup of Maple Syrup
- Pinch of Vanilla Powder
- Pinch of Fine Sea Salt
- Handful of chopped nuts, seeds or dried berries (optional)

I put Coconut Oil in a glass and to melt it I put the glass in a bowl with hot water. Alex mixed all ingredients to make an easy to pour mixture. He then poured the melted chocolate into moulds and I left it in the freezer for about 15 minutes to harden. That was it! Ready to eat straight after that. If you make too much chocolate, make sure you keep it in the fridge otherwise coconut oil might melt (:
=====================================================

videos.title: Ping Pong Ball Follows Running Water Tap | Kids Science
videos.description:
Here is a simple experiment for children at the kitchen that Alex loved. When a ping pong ball is placed straight under running water tap, it does not move away from the water stream. In fact, the ball sticks to it and follows it even when we move the tap. Here is what I told Alex and I hope it helps. The stream of water pulls air away around it. Then ping pong ball is filling this gap as it is pushed into it by air from the other side

videos.title: Candle And Water Simple Science Experiment
videos.description:
This is an impressive but simple experiment for children. We did it with Alex about two years ago, so it was Max's turn now. But this time I added a bit of a twist though.  I spread food colouring on the bottom of tea candle, lighted it and placed it at the centre of a plate with water. The good thing about tea candles, they float and that is very useful for this experiment. Then it can be covered with a jar, but we used a vase for the more dramatic result. The bigger is the jar the more water is sucked into it. 
EXPLANATION: The flame burns oxygen and the lack of it makes the candle go out, however, this is not the reason why water is sucked in. The actual reason is hidden in the temperature of the air and how the density of the air changes with temperature. When the candle is heating up the air, it expands getting out of the vase (you can actually see how bubbles of air are coming out in the video). When the candle goes out, the air starting to cool down. Cold air is denser and therefore it needs less space, so it shrinks sucking the water into the vase. 
=====================================================

videos.title: Science at Home: Red Cabbage Changing Colours (pH Indicator)
videos.description:
A quite dramatic colour change made this chemistry experiment really mesmerizing for Alex. After blending a few red cabbage leaves I poured purple cabbage juice into glasses. I added a little too many leaves, so I had to add more water to glasses for clearer colours. Then Alex started adding lemon juice, vinegar, baking soda and washing powder to separate glasses, leaving middle glass untouched. The purple cabbage juice turns red when it mixes with acids and turns blue/green when it mixes with base. What a fun way to test common household products for pH!
=====================================================

videos.title: Toddler I-Spy Bottle With Animals And Rainbow Rice
videos.description:
Here is a quick discovery bottle I made for Max. It could be used on a long car trip or a flight because of the number of questions I could ask him to find an answer to in the bottle, like what sea creature can you spot there or what blue animals can you find.
I the bottle I mixed animal shaped beads with leftovers of coloured rice from the sensory play we had a while back. But to make your own, you can use any small objects that fit into the bottle and lentils, rice or sand. Just don't forget to take a picture of all object to know what to ask later and make sure you secure the cap with sticky tape or glue

videos.title: Explore Black Markers with Chromatography | Kids Science
videos.description:
We are using a scientific method called chromatography to see what colours have been used by different manufacturers to make their black markers. Surprisingly black colour hides a bunch of bright colours. 
To take the experiment a bit further, we used permanent market too, but it does not dissolve in water. This gave a topic for discussion with Max about what kind of markers we would use in deferent situations. If we want to be able to wash it easily with water afterwards or we want drawing to stay even if we take it outside and it rains.

videos.title: How To Make A Simple Hollow Face Illusion From TheDadLab Book
videos.description:
Get TheDadLab BOOK https://thedadlab.com/book/
As promised on this special day I am revealing one of many new projects I have included in my debut TheDadLab BOOK.
We turned a photo of Max into a bowl shape for this illusion that shows us how our mind is sometimes convinced that it ‘knows best’, despite what our eyes are telling us. When I turn the face it looks like it continues looking at us. The illusion is possible because, in everyday life, we always see faces that are convex – bulging outwards, not curving inwards. And so our mind interprets what we are seeing that way.
=====================================================

videos.title: How To Make Eggshell Spin On A Plate | Fun Kids Activities
videos.description:
How fun is this breakfast trick?! It's magically spinning eggshell on a plate! The secret ingredient is water. I have dipped eggshell in water, and now it rotates instead of just sliding every time we tilt the plate. If instead of making eggshell wet, you spread water across the rim of the plate, you can make eggshell go in circles at the very edge of it. Try it now and share with us how did it go. videos.title: Fun Drawing Activity For Toddlers
videos.description:
Here is a different way to draw with markers Max was very excited to try: How to draw multiple objects at the same time. When I was making this, it was a bit of a challenge to align all four markers so that they touch paper at the same time. But there is a trick - use only 3 markers and you will not need to align them at all, proving something we were taught at school - "through any three noncollinear points, there is exactly one plane". In our case, the tips of markers are points and a piece of paper is a plane. So you will be able to easily draw with it on any flat and not very flat surface
=====================================================

videos.title: How To Make Natural Paint For Kids From Food At Home
videos.description:
Is it possible to make natural paints from food ingredients at home and make no mess? Max has proven it is. However, he had some help from an inappropriately white apron, convenient Plenty Handy Towels and his inherent precision. We used spinach for GREEN, turmeric for YELLOW, cacao powder for BROWN and strawberry with beets for shades of RED. We got some bright coloured paints and although they came with different tastes and smells varying from "I want to eat it" to "take it away from me" they were still good enough for creating a masterpiece. How messy are your kids with food?
=====================================================

videos.title: How to Pick Up a Ball With a Glass | Fun Science
videos.description:
Here’s something that’s really amazing, but it also takes a bit of skill and patience too! How can you pick up a ball with a glass without touching the ball itself? Place the glass over the ball and then start spinning the glass around in a circular motion. Once the ball starts spinning inside the glass, lift it from the table. Watch out! If the ball isn’t spinning enough, then you won’t be able to lift it.  Alex tried his best. It took a few goes, but he was so pleased when he did it. Can you keep the ball spinning long enough inside the glass to move it across the table? 
#TheDadLab #science #parentlife

videos.title: Fascinating Oil & Water Science Experiment for Kids
videos.description:
It's just mesmerising to watch how colour patterns formed in this experiment. You only need three simple ingredients, a minute to set it up, and you will have an exciting activity for your kids!
Food colouring is water based, and it doesn't dissolve oil, but if you mix them together, you will see a lot of tiny droplets of food colouring stuck in oil. However, food colouring is denser than oil and bit by bit droplets will submerge to the bottom of the oil layer, where they meet water and start colouring it. Have fun!
=====================================================

videos.title: How to Make MAGIC SAND that never gets wet | Kids Science
videos.description:
I have planned this activity for quite some time and the day has finally come for my boys to play with magic water repellent sand. It is difficult to determine what type of activity it is - a bit of art, a bit of science, but what I can say for sure it is messy (: To get ready, I went outside and sprayed a lot of fabric protector into a glass of coloured sand, mixed it and dried it. It took a few hours to dry. I have done this only once, but if you want to make the sand more water repellent, repeat the process two or three times.

videos.title: Fun Experiment with Frozen Water | Kids Science | AD
videos.description:
#ad | Inspired by Disney's Frozen 2 and #LEGO, this is a fun challenge to pick up a piece of ice with a string! The secret is to use salt and a bit of Frozen 2 magic (: Wet the string, put it flat on the ice, sprinkle a bit of salt and after ten seconds lift the string up. The ice should have been stuck to the string by then. What happens here is that salt dissolves in a thin layer of water above the ice. Salty water has a lower freezing temperature comparing to freshwater, so it makes ice to melt, absorbing the heat in the process. Ice takes some of that heat from water causing it to freeze back again trapping our string
#TheDadLab #Frozen2 #LEGOFrozen #playandlearn #Disney

videos.title: Liquids Science Experiment: Water Siphon | Kids Science
videos.description:
In this simple presentation, we see how siphons work. I asked Alex and Max to pay attention and tell me at what level should be water so that it starts going through the straw. So they did, had fun and learned something new.
A siphon can lift the water up without a pump, and that is the reason it has been used for thousands of years. But even today it is not 100% clear why it works. Perhaps the challenge is there because a few processes are happening at the same time for siphons to work. On the one hand, air pressure pushes down on the water, so that it stays in a glass and cannot get anywhere else, but once we give it a way out, it takes it and goes through a straw. On the other hand, when a straw is filled with water, the lower part of the siphon weights more than the upper part. So like with scales, the force of gravity pulls the heavy side down taking the water through the tube. This process relies on the property of water to stick to itself, creating an unbroken chain of drops. Anyway, I hope it wasn't too much information, and you would find it as fascinating as I did
#TheDadLab #physicsfun #homeschool #learnthroughplay

videos.title: How to Make a Perfect Shaped Hole with 1 Cut | One Cut Challenge
videos.description:
In this video, we cut a square hole, triangular hole, letter hole and a perfect star. Who knew that cutting holes in a piece of paper could be so fun and very educational. A fold&cut theorem states that any shape with straight sides can be cut out with a single cut if you fold a piece of paper the right way. So we started testing it. I asked Alex to make a square hole in the paper, and he made one with three cuts. Then I asked him to cut the same hole but cut only twice, and he made that happen too. Needless to say, he then found a way to cut a square hole with only one cut. After that, we started playing with other shapes too. The coolest thing was that we found a way to cut some letters too. "L" was a simple one. Some letters were tricky to find the solution. 
Anyway, I would like to challenge you to play with this theorem and share your cut-outs. This is a full family challenge, and I promise that everyone will have fun!

videos.title: 5 Awesome Static Electricity Experiments for Kids
videos.description:
There are different types of electricity, and today we are showing you five simple experiments with static electricity you could do at home. We see static electricity around us quite often, and it even builds on us. When we rub our feet on the carpet, we build up static electricity on the surface of our skin. It could make pieces of paper to stick to our feet or even zap something when we touch it. Did you know that lightning is also static electricity? The temperature of a lightning bolt is about 27,700 degrees Celsius (50000°F) that is five times hotter than the temperature of the surface of the Sun! If you rub a balloon on your hair, electrons are transferred from your hair to the balloon. This process gives the balloon a negative charge, and your hairs are left with a positive one. Almost like with a magnet, opposite charges will attract each other, and similar charges will repel.
I hope you get inspired to try some of these experiments. If you do try them, please tell me how it went.
#TheDadLab #science #learningthroughplay #homeschooling

videos.title: 5 Simple Ways to Make Dad's Portrait For Father's Day | Kids Crafts
videos.description:
In today's video, I will share 5 quick & easy Father’s Day Gift Ideas for kids, a Father's Day Special DIY. These are easy and fun ways for children to make something for their dad on Father's Day. I love them all, but let me know which ones you want to try out. 

⭕ TRACE THAT FACE:⠀
🔸You'll need:⠀
- clear plastic sleeve ⠀
- dad's portrait printout⠀
- permanent marker⠀
- coloured paper⠀
🔹 Instructions:⠀
Put the photo inside the plastic sleeve and trace the features with the marker. Don't forget the shadows and hair!⠀
Take out the picture and put in the coloured paper, that's your favourite colour.⠀

⭕ I LEAF YOU A LOT DAD:⠀
🔸You'll need:⠀
- paper⠀
- leaves, grass and flowers ⠀
- glue⠀
🔹 Instructions:⠀
trace out the outline of the face in the glue⠀
starting quickly before the glue dries! Add on your grass, stems, and flowers. Leaves look great as lips and hair.⠀

⭕ PASTA MAKES ME HAPPY:⠀
🔸You'll need:⠀
- dried pasta: spaghetti, stars, penne, rotini, and small shells! But feel free to use whatever you have.⠀
- paper⠀
- glue⠀
🔹 Instructions:⠀
Trace the face with glue, and add on the pasta! Since the pasta is dry, it's easy to snap things like spaghetti and make small lines.⠀

⭕ YOU COMPLETE ME:⠀
🔸You'll need:⠀
- paper⠀
- dad's portrait printout, but cut in half⠀
- coloured pencils⠀
🔹 Instructions:⠀
This one is easy! Start by glueing down half the face down on your blank paper.⠀
Just draw the other side of the face on the blank side of the paper in colour pencil.⠀

⭕ PIECES OF ME:⠀
🔸You'll need:⠀
- magazines⠀
- skin-toned/hair coloured craft papers⠀
- scissors⠀
- marker⠀
- plain paper⠀
- stick glue⠀
🔹 Instructions:⠀
In the magazines, find portraits of men that you think look like dad!⠀
Carefully cut out features, noses, ears, and so on.⠀
In the coloured paper, draw and cut things like hair and faces that you need.⠀
Glue your dad together on the plain paper!⠀
⠀

videos.title: How to Make Pom Pom Launcher from Toilet Paper Roll | Fun STEAM Activity for Kids
videos.description:
POM POM LAUNCHER! Great for sneak attacks or a game of pom-pom tag. It's really fun, and my boys were entertained for a while time with this quick and easy craft.⠀
⠀
⭕ Materials:⠀
- 2 toilet paper rolls⠀
- pencil⠀
- scissors⠀
- 2 rubber bands⠀
- tape⠀
- pom poms⠀
⠀
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) With one roll, fold it in half the long way, and then in half again the long way.⠀
(2) Carefully pierce the pencil near the top of your folded roll. Put the roll halfway onto the pencil.⠀
(3) On your unfolded roll, cut two parallel lines, about a centimetre deep and centimetre apart. Repeat on the opposite side of the same edge. Now you should have two tabs.⠀
(4) Place your rubber bands on the tabs and tape them in.⠀
(5) Put the pencil roll into the rubber band hole. The rubber bands should be on top and the pencils on the bottom.⠀
(6) Stretch the bands over the pencil.⠀
(7) Put the pom pom in the top, pull the pencil back and launch it!⠀
⠀

videos.title: 5 Cool DIY Father's Day Cards

Here are five amazing Father’s day crafts that you could make. They might look hard, but they’re simple if you follow the steps in the video. It does not matter if you are in quarantine or lockdown, you can easily make these Fathers Day cards for your dad

Pop Up Loud - You can get as detailed as much as you like. I took the extra time to cut out my letters and colour in ‘DAD’. Do whatever you like! The pop-up effect will make this card extra special. Make sure you really make your crease lines nice and crips for the pop up to work.

Pull my Finger - This one gets a little complicated with all the folding, so be sure to take it as slow as you need. Make sure not to fold up your photo once it’s in there; we want that part to stay nice. 

You Make My Heart Pop - If you aren’t sure how to print your photo into a heart, you can always print it and then cut it into shape. For this effect, be sure to angle only half of the pop-up tab, the half that connects to the heart.

Super Dad - This one is straightforward! Be sure to glue the smaller square inside, and the effect will work its magic. 

Dapper Dad - For the surprise inside, try and make sure the words aren’t already peaking through the shirt!

videos.description:
2 Amazing Hot and Cold Water Density Experiments
The science will amaze you if you just look close enough to things that surround you. What do you think would happen if you put hot and cold water in one container without mixing? Would "hot-air-balloon" principle work underwater where we heat water instead of air? We have done two cool experiments to answer those questions.
Water changes density depending on the temperature. So much so that cold water would not mix with hot water if you place it carefully in one container. The molecules in hot water are excited by the energy, and they move faster. So when they bump into one another, they bounce further away, leaving big gaps. This means that now the same volume of water has fewer molecules and weights less. The opposite happens with cold water making its density a bit higher.
Although the density difference is not that great, we can still see how hot water floats at the top while cold water stays at the bottom in our experiments. And this slight density difference has a significant impact on natural phenomena such as ocean currents.
#TheDadLab #scienceforkids #parenthood #homeschooling

videos.title: How to Keep Ice for Longer | Kids Science Experiments
videos.description:
Do you know how to keep ice for longer? Today we are exploring what materials delay melting of the ice better. The fact that clothes keep us warm confuses some children in thinking that the more materials we wrap around an ice cube, the hotter it is going to get inside. So make sure you ask children what they think is going to happen with the ice before going to the second part of the experiment.

We used: 
- six ice cubes 
- a glass container with lid
- a cup 
- one piece of each material: fabric, paper, kitchen foil, plastic
- a few rubber bands

We placed one ice cube in a cup. It should show us how fast ice melts naturally without any protection. So we could compare all other ice cubes to this one and see how good the material protects the ice. Then we used different materials to wrap all other ice cubes using rubber bands to hold the protective layer in place.
We waited for 2 hours before continuing our experiment. I was secretly looking at the ice cube in a cup to determine how long we need to wait. Ideally, this ice cube should be noticeably melted, so it is easier to compare with other ice cubes.
So when we unwrapped all ice cubes, we noticed that the fabric had done an excellent job.
We learned how different materials conduct heat. Metal (aluminium foil) is a good conductor of heat; that is why this material is used in making pans and pots. Metal quickly moves the heat from the flame to our food. Fabric isn't a good conductor of heat. That's why it's used to make blankets that keep us warm at night.

videos.title: 5 DIY Games To Keep Your Kids Learning
videos.description:
To get children excited about learning, we need to make it fun! Here are five simple brain teasers and games you can make at home for your children.⠀
⠀
⭕️ Use clear lids and coloured paper to make a brainteaser to play using logic and spatial awareness. First, glue different shapes each different colour to every lid. Then stack a few lids at the time creating unique shapes combinations. Make cards with these combinations, and you are ready to go!⠀
⠀
⭕️ Cut out three arrows and attach them to a paper plate with paper fasteners. Create cards drawing arrows pointing in different directions. Give the game to your children, and they would need to match directions of arrows on the paper plate to the ones on the cards by rotating arrows. For older children, you can replace arrows on the cards with directions: north, east, south, and west.⠀
⠀
⭕️ Cotton buds could be used to create brainteasers too. Colour each side with a different colour and create cards showing cotton buds, forming a unique shape. Children will need to find matching cotton buds to make a shape on a card matching all the colours at the same time.⠀
⠀
⭕️ Do you have plenty of empty boxes? It is time to make a fun toy from them. Get five identical squares and cut out four small squares from one of them. Cut out identical small squares in the same location on the next cardboard pieces but reduce the number of holes by one every time. Layer cardboard pieces together, glueing small squares on top of each other. Don't forget to colour the toy with markers!⠀
⠀
⭕️ Cut out colourful fish from paper and attach a paperclip where the mouth is. Use a marker to draw numbers on each fish. Make a fishing rod with a magnet and start fishing out fish in numeric order.⠀
⠀

videos.title: How To Make 3D Photo Frame Craft | DIY Gifts
videos.description:
I take millions of photos, forget hundreds of thousands of them, but I do print the best ones. There is just something about holding a finished framed photo that is much more satisfying than seeing the photo on a pocket-sized screen. This time I decided to do a special 3D photo-project. I chose a photo that could be easily divided into background, foreground and one layer in between. Then I printed three copies of the same photo. I cut out each layer. For the next step, I used adhesive foam dots to stick layers together and to attach the final photo to the frame. The result is just magical! This technique makes a picture to literally pop-out of the frame. In real life, the effect looks even better than in the video. So I hope you will find time to make your 3D photo print like this for yourself or as a gift for someone special.

videos.title: 5 Awesome Water Tricks | Kids Science Experiments with Water
videos.description:
Let’s play with some water and explore some of its weird scientific properties. Children are going to love these water tricks and will definitely want to learn how they work!

⭕️ Let’s explore some things that float on the surface of the water. Using a trap of water, you can show you paper clips easily float instead of sinking. Then, you can cut out a fun Dino friend but folding apiece of paper in half and cutting out some fun shapes. Make sure he has his 6 feet sticking out! When he’s ready, he’ll float on top of the water too.

⭕️ Did you know some things are afraid of water? Some things, like cinnamon, are hydrophobic. Gently tap a tablespoon of water onto a glass of water, having it float on top. When you stick your finger in, the cinnamon won’t get wet, and won’t stick to your finger!

⭕️ Cut a small square of paper, and fold it three times on the diagonal. Cut the widest part into a pedal shape. Unfold and add a yellow dot, and you have a flower. Fold all the pedals towards the centre. Make as many as you like. When you put them into the water, the flowers open up when they start to absorb the water! 

⭕️ This one is pretty magical. Draw a mouth, and be sure to colour in those teeth. Put your paper into a plastic bag, and only trace black lines. When you place the plastic bag into a cup of water and look down into it, the teeth marks have disappeared!

⭕️ Fill a plastic bag with water. Then, take some super sharp pencils and push them all the way through both sides of the bag. No water will spill! Pretty neat.

videos.title: How to Make Christmas Star | Easy DIY Christmas Decorations
videos.description:
DIY Christmas Decorations! Even over the holidays, I try to bring in some science! I thought since we wanted a nice big Christmas star, we could make one with some DIY skills and simple science. For the star, I cut five sticks that are similar down to the same height. Then, we lined them up in a line. To tie them together, we started off using rubber bands and connecting them in a zig-zag pattern, like a really long ‘Z’. This is the best time to put on the string lights. Wind them all the way down the sticks. Now, you can carefully fold your star shape! Tie it off one last time to keep it together.

This was an enjoyable and easy Christmas activity to do, and I love the way this looks. It’s easy thanks to the tension of the rubber bands holding this whole project together. Something so simple can make something so beautiful!
#DIYChristmasDecorations

videos.title: Learn to Add Numbers | DIY Game for Preschoolers
videos.description:
This addition machine is hungry for numbers! It shows children that there are multiple ways to get to the same number. It can grow with your children because you can put in any numbers you want.  Let me know if you make this addition machine!
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Gift Box style Cardboard Box ( the lid should fold over the top and front)
- Box cutter
- Two Paper Cups
- Pencil
- Two Colored Paper Squares
- Marker
- Tape
- Dry Erase Marker
- Pom Poms, paper scrunched into balls or any small soft objects
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Take your box and cut the top portion of the lid in half. Remove the half of the lid that's attached to the front, and put it aside. We'll need it for later.
(2) Turn the box, so the section we just cut is now the front. This makes the back of the box the new top. On this new top, trace two circles with the bottom of your paper cups, and use the box cutter to cut the circles out. 
(3) Cut our the bottoms of the paper cups, and place them into the holes. 
(4) Take the portion of the box we cut off and put in into the cut hole, making a lip to catch the balls and make it easier to take them out. 
(5) On the coloured paper, write an addition sign on one, and then an equal sign on the other. Tape the "plus" sign on the outside near the cups and the "equal" sign near the inside bottom. 
(6) Cut two squares of wide tape, and place them on both sides of the plus sign.
(7) Write in the numbers with a dry-erase marker
(8) Now use the machine to find the answer! Drop paper balls in each cups and count them up!

videos.title: Disappearing Flames Experiment | Kids Science Experiment
videos.description:
Try it only with adults supervision!!!
For today's experiment, we will explore the science of fire and learn some fire safety along the way. 
For this, you'll need tea lights, different sized blocks, and a glass jar that can cover all of these items. When we put the jar over the lit flames, candles go out one by one, from tallest to shortest. Why is that? 
Just like us, fire needs air to breathe. When we put the candles in a jar, we aren't letting any new air in. Fire breathes in the air and lets out smoke. The smoke rises towards the top of the jar. The fire keeps breathing the air until smoke fills the jar from top to bottom. Fire can't breathe smoke, so the flame goes out once the air is gone. 
This is why we are taught that in a fire emergency, we need to crawl towards the exit- that's where all the air is!

videos.title: Wow! Amazing DIY Cardboard Whale Automata Toy
videos.description:
You loved my previous DIY toy so much that I decided to show you one more idea of a simple machine that explores motion and force! This device uses the force we put on a wooden stick to make the top piece jump and spin. We themed our jumping bit like a blue whale, but I encourage you to come up with your own themes.⠀
⠀
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- 2 square pieces of cardboard⠀
- 2 rectangles of cardboard ⠀
- Paper straw⠀
- 4 circles of cardboard.⠀
- 2 wooden skewers⠀
- Scissors⠀
- Hot glue⠀
⠀
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Glue the cardboard pieces together to make a box. ⠀
(2) Glue together the circles - so you now have 2 thick ones. ⠀
(3) Put one skewer through the cardboard box, with a cardboard circle in the middle. The circle should be pierced off centre. ⠀
(4) On the short side of the box, make a hole to fit the straw. Glue it in. ⠀
(5) Put the other skewer through the straw, and balance the other circle on top of the pierced circle.⠀
(6) Glue water to the skewer and the whale to the straw. ⠀
(7) Watch the whale blowing water!⠀

videos.title: How to Make a Silver Egg | Simple Science for Kids
videos.description:
When you hold the egg close to the flame, it gets covered in soot. Soot repels water, similar to oil. When we put our sooty egg in the water, it creates a small air bubble around it. This bubble reflects light, and makes the egg look like it’s made of silver or ice! Once you take the egg out, it will just be a soggy egg. 
Water is great to experiment with because it can do lots of things! It’s exciting to see what happens when you combine things - like soot and an eggshell with water. You’ll never know what will happen!

videos.title: Teach Kids Basic Addition with Toy Cars | Creative Math Activities
videos.description:
Cars and math make a great team when it comes to learning addition! I love this addition game because it shows how many different answers there can be to the same question. This is great for kids that are active, or love to solve puzzles. ⠀
⠀
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Coloured Paper⠀
- Toy cars⠀
- Glue⠀
- Scissors⠀
- Ruler⠀
- Marker⠀
⠀
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Take the small square of colour paper, and cut off 2 corners, so it resembles and house (a square with a triangle on it).⠀
(2) With the ruler and marker, draw a horizontal line where the triangle meets the square. Can you see it now? From the centre of this line, draw a vertical line straight down, making a ’T’ shape. ⠀
(3) On your smaller colour paper scraps, write a number, any number. I did 5. I then made multiple math houses and wrote the numbers 3, 7, and 6. ⠀
(4) On more coloured paper scraps, write the numbers 1-5. Glue them to the top of some toy cars.⠀
(5) Now, park two cars in the garage that add up to the houses number!⠀
⠀

videos.title: Trick-or-Treating at Home | Halloween Kids Activity
videos.description:
I do not want my kids to miss out on trick-or-treating this year, but I want to keep them safe. So this year we are trick-or-treating in our garden. It is like a candy treasure hunt. Children will have fun and get their long-waited candy.

Simple Ideas for Halloween 2020: A Spooky, GLOW-Tastic Twist on Traditional Trick or Treating!!

Can't trick or treat the conventional way due to the pandemic? No worries!! I am determined not to let Covid-19 ruin your first fall holiday. 

With all the social distancing, we need to find a safe way to celebrate, for sure. By staying cautious and exceptionally creative, we can altogether rejoice Quarantine-o-ween. So, I'm here to show you a Halloween Hunt that you won't want to miss! 

Composing a candy hunt at home will enchant your kids without risking their safety or the wellbeing of others. Read on how to innovate traditional Trick-Or-Treat with a "Candy Treasure Hunt" without leaving your home or backyard. 

- Go DIY, buy your kids favourite candies and glue them inside paper cups using tape. Put each paper cup with candy upside down in the garden.
- Another great way is to put the sweets inside biodegradable balloons and blow them up. To make it more fun, put LED tea light candles inside the balloons for a glow in the dark Halloween hunt experience.
- Finally, channel your decorating soul and celebrate Halloween with pumpkins and lights, and other creepy sights. Crave and fill up the pumpkin with delicious candies and treats for the sweetest surprise for your little ones.

Now that the garden has been set-up with the balloons, pumpkins, ghoulish cups, and lights, are you ready for some Halloween fun? Wait for it to get darker, then invite your kids to invade the treasure hunt! Let them wrap up sweets and prizes into individual buckets. Kids will be spotting stuff glowing in the grass, and it would feed the excitement.

So, let's get creative and take Halloween fun to a whole new level. It would be great to fuse these simple ideas into our usual yearly Halloween tradition. Let's make it spooky as always but keeping everybody safe during these uncertain times.

Happy Halloween kids activity!

videos.title: Paper Bag Tree Craft | Dried Leaves Craft Ideas
videos.description:
Let’s create a 3D sculpture of an autumn tree! In the fall, we can clearly see how unique are shapes of different types of trees. With the project, you’ll be able to turn your paper bag into any kind of trees you like. I was going for more of an apple tree. Please let me know if it looks like one (:⠀
⠀
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Paper bag⠀
- Leaves⠀
- Glue stick⠀
- Scissors⠀
⠀
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Fold up a paper bag. You’ll want to cut a lot of medium-sized slits, about 2cm each. The cuts should go about 2/3rds of the way down the bag. Be sure to cut through both sides of the paper. These are your tabs.⠀
(2) Open the bag up, and start gathering all the tabs together at the base. Squeeze them together really tight! When they’re close together, start to twist from the base of all the tabs upward gently. ⠀
(3) Taking 2 or 3 tabs at a time, twist them together to make tree branches. Leave the last third of the branch and just twist out the singular tabs. These make some skinnier branches. ⠀
(4) Glue the leaves to the ends of the twisted branches. ⠀
Our tree sculpture is complete!⠀

videos.title: Paper Cup Hippo Craft Idea | Easy to make DIY Toy
videos.description:
Let's craft a cute hippo toy! By changing the tension on the string, we can open the mouth of our hungry hippo a little for a small snack, or huge for a great big dinner! You can take the idea further and use this technique to create other animals. What animal is your child's favourite? 
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Paper cups
- Coloured paper 
- String
- Glue
- Pencil
- Scissors
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) On the first paper cup, we're going to want the cup to be able to fold in half. To achieve this, draw two vertical lines on either side of the paper cup. The lines should touch the bottom, but not the top rim. 
(2) Using these lines, make two semi-circles so that they're joined together. It should look like you have two 'U's that are connected. On the bottom of the cup, draw a small circle near the top of a 'U' that you string could pass through.
(3) Cut out around the 'U's, be sure to also cut on those vertical lines. Cut out or pierce the hole on the bottom. Gently fold the bottom. 
(4) Cut out and glue on a tongue, eyes, teeth and ears. 
(5) Take a string, and thread it through the hole. Glue it to the top of your hippo's mouth. That's the head!
(6) On your second paper cup, draw a triangle on the bottom of the cup that touches all the sides. Draw a small circle near the top rim on the side. Cut these out.
(7) Thread the string through the triangle, and then through the hole. Tie it off and add a paper tab. Glue the head into the triangle hole. Your puppet is done!

videos.title: How to Make Helicopter Craft | Simple Kids Crafts
videos.description:
This DIY paper toy is very fun to play with! It works with a rubber band, that when twisted and released, makes our propeller go and fly our helicopter across the floor. 

⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- 2 paper cups
- Coloured paper
- Marker
- Bead
- Twist Tie
- Paper straw
- Scissors
- Glue
- Pencil
- Rubber band
- Skewer

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Take one paper cup and cut it in half vertically. Take one of these halves and cut off the rim. Crease it in half, so your longest sides are touching. You should have a sort of tube shape.
(2) With another paper cup, bottom side up, draw a large oval near the rim. Cut it out. Put your tube in this hole. It should look like a teapot, or watering can.
(3) Decorate helicopter with coloured paper or markers.
(4) On the top, pierce a hole in the centre. Loop the rubber band around itself to tie it to the centre of the skewer. Thread a bead onto the rubber band. 
(5) Thread the rubber band through the cup, so that the bead and skewer are on top, and the band is inside. Stretch the band, and using the twist tie, attach the band to the straw.
(6) Attach your propeller blades. Now, after you twist the straw on the bottom and release it, your top propeller will spin!

videos.title: Simple Paper Cup Craft That Moves | Crafts for Kids
videos.description:
This little toy is so quackin' cute! Like some paper cup crafts we've made before, this one is really easy to make. You just need to make some strategic cuts to make this quacky friend move. You colour the outside cup to make a penguin or a turkey instead. What bird would you make?
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- 2 paper cups
- Coloured paper
- Pencil
- Scissors
- Glue
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Take one paper cup, and draw on and cut out the shapes as shown.
(2) Take another paper cup, and put it into the cut cup. Mark the top of the M shape and where the edges of the two slots are. Take it out. The two long slot points should be connected with a long U shape, where the top of the M points should be connected with a short, upside-down U.
(3) Cut along the lines, and pop them out. The big U's should be up, and the short U should be down.
(4) Reinsert the second cup into the first. Put the big tabs through the slots to make the wings, and keep the small one down for the beak.
(5) Cut out and glue on the eyes, top and bottom beak and feet. 
(6) When you move the cups apart, your duck's mouth and wings move!

(3) Cut out a paper circle using a paper clip to trace a perfect circle on a square. Fold this circle in half, and glue on fins and eyes. Draw on a mouth.

videos.title: HOW TO MAKE A PAPER SPIDER | EASY CRAFTS FOR KIDS
videos.description:
Want to make a bug friend? I promised this one is very friendly and loves to wiggle around!
⭕ MATERIALS:
- Coloured paper
- Scissors⠀
- Glue
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Take a thin strip of paper and fold it to make an L shape. Then, start crossing the pieces over. So left to right, and up to down, then right to left and down to up. videos.title: How to Make a Simple Pinball Machine with Cardboard for Kids
videos.description:
Holiday time, when we gather around the fire with friends and family, and maybe exchange a gift or two. This year might look different for a lot of people around the world. It really got me thinking about what my holidays were like as a child. The toys definitely weren't super technical like they are today! I wanted to share a little bit of these analogue holiday memories with you, and I came up with a make-shift pinball machine. Did you have a toy like this growing up?

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Cardboard
- Wooden clothespin
- Wooden popsicle stick
- Coloured paper
- Plastic or rubber ball
- Boxcutter
- Hot glue gun
- Marker
- Glue

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Take a large piece of cardboard, and cut it according to the picture.
(2) Using the hot glue gun, glue the smaller cut piece to the largest piece, like you're building a gingerbread house.
(3) Glue the popsicle stick onto the top of the clothespin. Then, glue the opposite side on the clothespin to the bottom of our cardboard shape, placing it in the corner.
(4) Taking additional thin strips of cardboard, glue them to the interior of the large cardboard shape according to the video. You should have a think "alleyway" and three U-shapes.
(5) Cut triangle shapes and rectangles out of the colourful paper, labelling the rectangles as 20, 15, 10, and then "Pinball". Glue the sign at the top, the points in the 'U’-shapes, and the triangles pointing up in the alleyway.
(6) Tilt your pinball machine. When you put down the popsicle stick and release it, it flings the ball up the alleyway and into the points area!

videos.title: How to Craft a Crocodile Toy | Simple Paper Crafts
videos.description:
Do you know the difference between an alligator and a crocodile? The easiest difference to spot is their snouts! Crocodiles have V-shaped snouts and interlocking teeth. When crocodiles close their mouth, you can see both upper and lower teeth. Alligators, on the other side, have U-shaped snouts, and they show only upper teeth when their mouth is closed. Which one are you going to make with me today? Let me know!
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Paper cups
- Coloured paper
- Scissors
- Glue
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Cut 4 horizontal cuts into the side of a paper cup. Then, cut the bottom out. Carefully cut the strip second from the bottom and the one closes to the top rim in half. Push these tabs out, and crease them towards the ends to make legs.
(2) Cut out two spikes pieces of paper and a long trapezoid shape. Make it pointy to rounded to decide if you’re going to make a crocodile or an alligator! Glue the spikes shapes onto the long sides of the trapezoid. Push your slides up to make teeth. Do this again, so you have a top and bottom set.
(3) Glue these to the inside of the bottom of the cup to make your mouth. (4) Cut out and glue on a tongue that comes out the back of the cup. Cut out a strip and attach to the roof of the mouth, and have it also come all the way out the back. Attach these pieces together.
(5) Cut out eyes, spine pieces, and a tail cover, and glue these on.
(6) Pull the tail and watch him bite!

videos.title: Racing Game DIY | How to Make Race Car Game with Cardboard for Kids
videos.description:
Let’s build a game with cardboard for children to steer their car up the curving road by pulling strings!
⭕ MATERIALS:
- Cardboard
- Paper straw (plastic or paper)
- Paper
- String
- Marker
- Scissors or box cutter
- Hot glue gun

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Draw a curving road through the middle of your piece of cardboard- don’t forget the lane dividers!
(2) Draw a box around the road, about 3 cm away from the edge. Mark the empty areas you want to cut out and remove them.
(3) Cut off two small pieces of your straw. Glue them to the top corners of the cardboard.
(4) Taking a small rectangle of cardboard, we can turn it into a car by cutting it to shape and adding craft paper. Place a hole the size of a coin in the centre.
(5) Take two more pieces of cardboard, roughly the size of your first large piece, and glue their edges together to make an ‘L’ shape. Put the road on an angle and glue it to make a triangle.
(6) Glue the centre of a long string to the top back of the car. Thread one end of the string through one straw piece.
(7) Cut a small circle from a piece of cardboard that fits inside the car.
(8) Place it in the hole, and try the keep in on the road as you pull the car up!

videos.description:

videos.title: How To Make a Sock Snowman | DIY Christmas Craft
videos.description:
How To Make a Sock Snowman | DIY Christmas Craft
Do you want to build a snowman? You can easily make a sock snowman not even leaving your house and have it for decorations or play. Why don't you make a big happy snow family? 
⭕ MATERIALS:
- Clean socks
- Uncooked rice
- String
- Paper
- Glue
- Beads or buttons

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS: 
(1) Take your clean sock and fill it with rice, to the heel. Take a length of string and tie it off. Cut off the excess sock at the top.
(2) Take two lengths of string, tying them around the sock tube making 3 lumps. Make one small to for the head, and the other big to form the bottom.
(3) Roll paper for a carrot nose. Glue the nose and eyes on. 
(4) Use a cut-off excess piece (or use another contrast coloured sock) to form the beanie. Put it on the head and use more string to tie it off. Use a strip of sock to create a scarf. 
(5) Your snow person is all bundled up and ready to play!

videos.title: Christmas Tree Art Tutorial | Salt Painting for Kids
videos.description:
Simple Christmas Tree Art Tutorial with Salt Painting for Kids
Do you know why we put out salt on the streets during the winter months? Salt dissolves in water and lowers its freezing point, so it takes temperature to drop even lower to turn salted water into ice. Our picture today will use salt, and watercolour paints too.

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Colour paper
- PVA glue
- Salt
- Watercolour paints
- Water
- Brush
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS: 
(1) Create your design with glue on the paper. Cover the glue with salt and let dry.
(2) Use water to activate the paints, and lightly dab them onto the salt. The paint will flow and blend into the salt, creating a cool blending effect!

videos.title: Christmas Activity for Preschool | Science Experiments for Kids
videos.description:
Christmas Activity for Preschool | Science Experiments for Kids.
Let’s bring a science experiment to a winter wonderland! This simple and Christmas activity to do with young children, but I liked fizzing the magical Christmas Wonderland myself too. It is a simple way to make me feel happy as a child again (: What makes you feel like a child?

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Baking soda
- Food colouring
- Glitter
- Water
- Vinegar
- Paper and tape
- Snowflake or other winter moulds
- Pipette or spoon
- Tray

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS: 
(1) Put baking soda, food colouring, glitter together in a tray. Slowly add small amounts of water, and then mix. We’re looking for the consistency of wet sand. Wet and moldable. 
(2) When it reaches this point, put the sand in your moulds of choice. You can make a Christmas tree mould by rolling a piece of paper in a cone and taping it shut. 
(3) Freeze the moulds. 
(4) Remove your moulds and place them into the tray. Sprinkle them with more baking soda.
(5) Taking a small amount of vinegar in a pipette or spoon, drop it onto the moulds. Watch them fizz and disappear into the snow!

videos.title: DIY Safe Christmas Slime | Christmas Science Experiment
videos.description:
How to make Safe Christmas Slime? If you mix cornstarch and water, you will get a suspension that acts like a solid when you put pressure on it, but then it can flow like a liquid. - 1 small cup of water
- Food colouring of your choice
- Biodegradable glitter
- Tray
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
Mix all the ingredients into a tray together. Try making a snowball by squeezing this slime hard and then let it go to see how it turns to liquid.

videos.title: How to Make a Ball Sorting Machine | DIY Cardboard Games for Toddlers
videos.description:
How to Make a Ball Sorting Machine | DIY Cardboard Games for Toddlers
There is a big chance we all have an abundance of empty cardboard boxes after Christmas. Let's turn them into toys! There is no such thing as "too many toys" is there? (: Here is a simple DIY ball sorter that will help you sort all the balls you have at home by size while keeping your child entertained and curious about how this mysterious machine works.

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Cardboard box
- Craft paper
- Rubber Balls (Three different sizes)
- Scissors 
- Marker
- Glue
- Paperclip

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Cut an empty cardboard box to make shapes I show in the video. Glue them together so that it looks almost like the bottom of a vending machine. 
(2) On a smaller piece of cardboard that will fit inside the box, make holes that will easily have the two smaller sizes of rubber balls through them. One box for each size. 
(3) Glue this slotted piece inside the box at an angle, adding two divider pieces so there are three slots. 
(4) Score the excess piece of cardboard at the back of the box and fold it down to make a lid. Mark out and cut out a hole at the top where you ramp is. Cover the top half of the exposed part with a piece of paper with three different sized dots, matching your balls.
(5) When you drop your balls, watch how they get sorted in different sections!

videos.title: How to Make 3D Paper House Easy | DIY Kids Paper Craft
videos.description:
Did you like playing with a dollhouse growing up? Here is a paper one that children can quickly make on their own! This playhouse can be designed in any way they’d like to suit any figurines they already have. After children are done playing, the house could be easily folded for compact storage. 

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Craft paper
- Scissors 
- Marker
- Glue
- Paperclip

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Take a paper square and fold it half one way, then in half the other way, so it’s like there’s a plus sign in the paper. Cut one of the pluses legs to the centre. You should have two tabs that are still connected to the paper. 
(2) In the top left square, draw a door. In the bottom left square, draw a path. In the top right square, draw a window. Put glue on the bottom right square. Place the bottom left corner on the top right, so it makes half a 3-D box. Fold the bottom path in the middle towards the centre, and fold the whole thing in half, so it appears to be one square.
(3)  Repeat step 2, but with 3 other rooms of the house. Glue the “walls” together, leaving one pair unglued. Paperclip this wall together. 
(4) Cut out details.
(5) Fold up your house and take it anywhere you’d like!

videos.title: How to Make Paper Snake | Easy Kids Crafts
videos.description:
#Shorts Do you know how a snake moves without arms or legs? They use their muscles to push their scales against the ground or other objects and push the snake forward. We can see this effect in a similar way when we make a paper chain!

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Craft paper
- Marker
- Scissors⠀
- Glue

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Cut out several strips of paper in two different colours. Stack them up, and cut them in half. Take one colour, and with glue, connect it to make your first loop. Take the second colour, and loop it through the first loop, and glue it shut to start your paper chain. I made mine 16 links long. 
(2) Cut out snake's head with a tongue, glue on or draw on eyes. Glue to your last link. Look at that snake going!

videos.title: Fun Scissor Skill Activity For Preschoolers With Stickers
videos.description:
As a wise robot once said: “Bleep...Bloop”, which simply translates to ‘Snip snip...scissors beats paper’. This fun robot activity helps children to practice cutting along the lines and while switching directions. The skills used for this task are essential for those needed to complete everyday tasks. So, whether you have your very own robot for daily chores or not, this activity is will help guide the way. You never know, maybe one day your child could be using these to build their very own robot!

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Paper / card
- Marker
- Stickers (here we have used robot stickers)
- Scissors

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Cut strips of card or paper, big enough for your child to hold.
(2) Using one strip of paper, place a sticker at the top of one side.
(3) Draw dashed lines using the pen. For beginners, draw a straight line from the sticker to the bottom of the paper. To adapt this, you can draw lines that curve or zigzag.
(4) Taking your scissors, place another small sticker (we used a robots arm) on top of the straight blade. When you begin cutting it should look like your scissors are trying to catch the sticker at the end of the line.
(5) Now let your children use the scissors to catch the robot!

videos.title: DIY Cardboard Game that is Easy to Make | Fun Space Game
videos.description:
DIY cardboard games easy to make! 
Let’s build a space game with cardboard! This is a scrolling game where you have to fly your spaceship by avoiding crashing it into asteroids, dwarf planets and perhaps some flying saucers. Ready, set, launch!

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Cardboard
- 2 pencil
- 2 wooden skewers
- Plastic caps from plastic bottles
- Long strip of paper with a space background 
- Paper spaceship
- String
- Scissors or box cutter
- Hot glue gun

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Cut out a large piece of cardboard using the video as reference. The four corners should be small rectangles, and the sides should be long rectangles. Glue the long pieces to the edges of the largest uncut piece to make a box. 
(2) Take a pencil and pierce it through 2 of the smaller pieces of cardboard. Put hot glue around the pencil between the two pieces. Hot glue the cardboard to the inside of the box. Repeat with one more pencil and other two cardboard pieces.
(3) Repeat step 2 with wooden skewers, but do not add hot glue around them. On one skewer, piece the centre of the bottle cap and put it in the centre of the skewer. Put another pierced cap on the exposed end of the lower pencil. 
(4) Tie the string in a loop around the wooden skewer, making sure it goes around the bottle cap. 
(5) Loop the strip of paper around the coloured pencils and glue it shut. 
(6) Glue a spaceship to the string, pointing up to the pencils. It should go left and right when you turn the bottle cap.
(7) With a piece of paper, cover everything but the space background and the two bottle caps. 
Your travelling spaceship is ready!

videos.title: How to Make Paper Peacock | Kids Paper Crafts
videos.description:
This craft is meant for a child and a parent to enjoy making together. How strong are your origami skills? Let's start with something simple to find out! Fold a paper crane and add colourful feathers to it!
⭕ MATERIALS:
- Craft paper
- Marker
- Scissors⠀
- Glue
⠀
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Take several thin strips of paper in different colours. Each strip should be slightly shorter than the last. Taking the shortest one, make a loop and glue it shut. Taking the next shortest piece, glue one end to the loop, and then glue the detached end to the top, making a slightly longer loop that is over the first. Repeat with all your strips. I did four colours and made six total loops of varying sizes.
(2) Taking a square of paper, fold it on a diagonal to make a triangle, with the longest side being the crease. Take the top of the paper, the part that's not attached to anything, and fold it down and off to the side, so the left edge is now flush with the bottom edge. Repeat on the other side.
(3) Repeat step two but with these smaller triangles. Open up the shape one time. Then start to fold it towards the centre, then crease it down. It makes a sort of fortune cookie type of shape. Make sure to crease everything down nice and firm. 
(4) Open up the top of one triangle tip, and bend it to make a head. Cut off the tip of the other triangle. Sit down the bird and let it open up on its own. 
(5) Take the larger loops and glue them together with hot glue. Insert them into the cut end to make the tail. Take the two smaller pieces and glue them towards the centre of the bird to make the wings.

videos.title: Teach Kids Basic Addition with DIY Paper Apple Tree
videos.description:
Let's use apples to check our math! This educational craft for math activity clearly shows the representation of addition, and it makes finding results fun for children.⠀
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Coloured paper⠀
- Pencil⠀
- Scissors⠀
- Glue⠀
- Ruler⠀
- Box Cutter⠀
⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Draw a top of a tree and the trunk. Cut out the shapes with the scissors.⠀
(2) Glue down the leaves onto the plain white piece of paper.⠀
(3) Draw a 2cm vertical line on the bottom left of the tree trunk. Go up a centimetre, and draw another line. Repeat again, so you have 3 lines on the left. Repeat on the right. You should have 6 lines in total, 3 sets of 2. ⠀
(4) On a surface that's safe to cut on, use the box cutter to cut out the lines. Glue down only the top third of the tree trunk. ⠀
(5) Taking the strips of paper, thread them through the notches we made, so the paper strip peaks through the middle of our trunk. Be sure to crease the ends to make tabs, so they don't slide out! ⠀
(6) Glue 1cm paper squares of paper onto the trunk, in-between our sliding ones. Write "+" on one, and then "=" sign on the other.⠀
(7) Using the pull tabs, write the number 1-5 on the top two sliders, and then 1-10 on the bottom one. ⠀
(8) Cut the red paper into 10 small circular apples for your tree. As you do the math, you can add apples to the tree and count them!⠀

videos.title: Simple Ice Science Experiment for Valentine
videos.description:
Valentine's day is just around the corner, and this little heart garland is a great way to fuel your kids' imagination. Teach your kids the wonder of science with this heart experiment and watch their love of science grow. Learning through play is fun and a great way to share learning and science with your little ones. This activity shows how salt interacts with ice to fuse the string and helps children understand science through play.
⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Glass of water⠀
- Red food colouring
- Heart-shaped ice tray
- Plate or tray
- String that can absorb water
- Salt

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Add a few drops of red food colour to a glass of water and mix⠀
(2) Transfer water to the heart-shaped ice tray.⠀
(3) Put the ice tray in a freezer until the water is completely frozen ⠀
(4) Take ice hearts out and place them in a row on a plate.
(5) Soak string in water thoroughly
(6) Lay the string over the row of ice hearts
(7) Add a pinch of salt to each heart where the string and the ice meet
(8) Wait 5 seconds and then lift the string to see how it fused with ice hearts.

⭕ SCIENCE EXPLANATION
What happens here is that salt dissolves in a thin layer of water the ice has. Salty water has a lower freezing temperature than fresh water, so it makes ice to melt, absorbing the heat in the process. Ice takes some of that heat from water causing water to freeze back again trapping our string.

videos.title: Rainbow Science Experiment to Do at Home for Valentine | Simple Kids Science
videos.description:
This experiment puts a new spin on the old volcanic eruption experiment. Using hearts to keep it Valentine-themed is a fantastic way to get your kids interested in science and art. Fuel their imagination, creativity and love of science with a colourful baking soda heart eruption. This experiment is fun for parents and kids and will fuel their love of learning and curiosity.

⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Baking soda⠀
- Different shades of food colouring
- Water
- Heart-shaped ice tray
- Vinegar
- Hand wash

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Add a few drops of food colouring to baking soda, add a little bit water and mix
(2) Repeat with different colours.⠀
(3) Add the mixtures to a heart ice tray⠀
(4) Freeze until solid
(5) Lay them out in a deep bowl
(6) Add hand wash to vinegar and mix
(7) Pour the mixture over the hearts and watch them fizz
(8) Mix up the foam to create colourful art

⭕ SCIENCE EXPLANATION
When we mix vinegar and baking soda, they react and produce a gas - carbon dioxide. We added soap into the mix. So the gas blows bubbles, creating a lot of foam.

videos.title: CUT THE GRASS | SCISSOR SKILL ACTIVITY
videos.description:
Is that a nose I can see? This scissor activity encourages children to cut the grass and see who is hiding behind. Children love surprises, even more, when they can be the ones to reveal it. Practising scissor skills has never been so fun. Is it a creepy crawly? Is it a patch of pretty flowers? You’ll have the cut the grass to find out!

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Plain paper
- Coloured card (green is necessary)
- Pen (optional)
- Scissors
- Glue stick

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) With your coloured card, make an animal - here we have used tan, brown, red, orange, yellow and green to create a hedgehog in an autumnal scene
(1a) Using the pen, you can draw a face on your animal or add any finer details, if you wish
(2) Glue each piece to the plain piece of paper, then put it to one side.
(3) Getting a new piece of green card, cut strips down the horizontal side. Make sure to stop around an inch from the bottom.
(4) Put a line of glue along the bottom of the paper and stick the grass on top.
(5) Once completed, let your child use the scissors to cut the grass and reveal who is hiding!

videos.title: How to Power a Light Bulb with a Balloon | Simple Science Experiment with Static Electricity
videos.description:
#Shorts This mind-blowing experiment is guaranteed to fuel your child’s imagination and make them eager to learn science. The magic balloon will teach your child about static electricity and will leave them fascinated. The balloon that makes light is sure to make them fall in love with learning. We’ve used a heart-shaped balloon for Valentine’s day.
⠀
⭕ MATERIALS
- Heart-shaped balloon⠀
- Woolen hat or clothing
- Fluorescent light bulb
- Dark room 

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS
(1) Blow up the balloon⠀
(2) Let your children rub it vigorously on a woolly hat for a few minutes to build up a static charge on the balloon⠀
(3) Bring the balloon close to a light bulb and watch it light up for a moment
(4) Make the room dark for greater effect

videos.title: TRIM THE LION'S MANE | SCISSOR SKILL ACTIVITY
videos.description:
When a lion flaunts its mane, it shows he is ready to rule the pride. So if your lion's hair is in need of a tame, this activity will help turn him from a little cub to a powerful bit cat. It is a great activity for children who are confident in using scissors but still want to challenge their skills. It encourages lots of practice and focus as they cut the lines in a range of different directions. Now let's get those mane's fit for a king!

⭕ MATERIALS:
- Paper /card (in a selection of colours)
- Marker
- Glue
- Scissors

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) On a small piece of a yellow card, use your marker to draw the outline of a lion's head and cut it out.
(2) Draw on a lion's face
(3) Turning your lion's face on to its front, use your glue to stick strips of multicoloured paper all around to make its mane.
(4) Turn your lion back over. On each strip of paper, draw different lines to indicate where to cut - you can draw lines that are straight, curved, zigzag, vertical, horizontal and as many as you like.
(5) Once completed, your children can use the scissors to trim and tame the lion's mane, just in time to rule over the pride.

videos.title: Simple Density Science Experiment with Two Glasses
videos.description:
Simple density experiments you can try in your kitchen now. We started by putting a glass of water on top of a glass of vegetable oil. That is a cool experiment on its own, but let's focus on density here. After we moved the card that separated glasses a little bit to create a small gap for liquids to connect, water and oil started moving. In the end, we had oil in the top glass and water in the bottom glass. It was time to turn our structure upside down and watch the flow of these liquids again. It can continue forever as long as you continue flipping glasses. But then we tried the same experiment with four liquids: water, coloured rubbing alcohol, handwash and oil.

videos.title: How to Make Salt or Sugar Water Density Rainbow Tower | Simple Kids Science
videos.description:
This saltwater density tower experiment will help you and your children understand density better. Density is the mass of a material per unit volume, and it is a fixed number for each material. The density of water is 997 kg/m³; however, we can increase it by adding salt and sugar to it. In this experiment, we were adding a different amount of salt to each glass of water. When the salt dissolves, it increases the mass of water without changing the volume very much, which means that the saltwater solution's density becomes higher than freshwater. That is why we could make this beautiful salt density tower.
Just a word of caution, when you are pouring colourful salty water into a big jar, you need to be very careful. Otherwise, you will end up with a jar full of salty brown water. Make sure you use small pieces of paper and funnel with a paper straw, as we show in the video.

videos.title: 5 MINUTES CRAFTS : 5 DIY Your Kids will LOVE!
videos.description:
Let’s make 5 Amazing DIY Toys with a dash of science that your kids will surely love!

00:03 - Velcro Dot Craft Sticks (Popsicles)

Materials: 
Craft Sticks (Popsicle Sticks) Depending on your choice of color and size andPieces
Velcro dots ( Depending on your desired pieces/pack) You can buy the Stick ready kind or the ones you can manually glue on.

Instructions:
Attach the velcro dots to every end of the popsicle sticks. Make sure to attach the same kind of dot on the same side and on the other side. The velcro dots stick very well and it doesn’t come off easily even after months of playing with it. Remember to let the glue set the number of hours suggested on the packaging!

Hand them to the kids and watch them play. Show them how it works by demonstrating that the tabs stuck to each other before they can start making or forming their own popsicle stick projects.

00:37- Easy Horn

Materials Needed:
A piece of Unblown Balloon
A piece of Rubber Band
A piece of clean water bottle (unused or used be sure its clean! 😉)
And a Cutter

Instructions:
Cut the top part of the water bottle using the cutter (as shown in the video). Next is to cut a small part of the balloon in the mid section small enough to fit in the lip and in the collar part of the water bottle. Place the balloon in the lip and collar part of the water bottle and secure the opening (the part that has been cut) with the rubber band until tightened and Tada! You now have a handy-dandy horn! You can do it with other colors too!

1:36- The Diving Ketchup

Materials Needed:
Empty and Clean water bottle
A packet of ketchup
Water-Plenty enough to fill the water bottle

Instructions:
It is very important to select a ketchup packet that will float in water. Test a couple packets by placing them one by one in the glass of water. Choose the one that floats the highest at the surface of the water.
Remove any labels on the plastic water bottle.
Fill the plastic water bottle with water, leaving about an inch of air at the top.
Fold the ketchup packet in half lengthwise and push it into the bottle. Double check that it floats.
Screw the cap tightly back on to the bottle.
Now, it's time to command the ketchup! Holding the bottle upright in one hand, squeeze the bottle gently. What happens to the ketchup packet? Now, release the pressure of your squeeze and watch what happens. By experimenting with the amount of pressure you apply to the bottle, can you make the packet levitate in the middle of the bottle?
Now that you have mastered the ability to get the ketchup to sink, rise, and hover, find yourself an audience and get dramatic about it! Command the ketchup to move 'up', 'down', and to 'stop'. Your audience won't believe their eyes!

2:20- Magic Sequins Sublimation
Materials Needed:
Cardboard Enough to fit the Sequin Pillow case.

Instructions:
Place the cardboard in a sequin pillow case, close it, and Hand them to the kids and watch them play. Your kids will be amazed by the magic they see as they touch the pillow case!

3:19- Empty Squeezy Rocket Launchers
Materials: 
Empty Squeezy water bottles,
Cardboard,
Straws,
Scissors,
Glue/sellotape,
Blue tack,
Plasticine,

Instructions:
FOR THE BOTTLE
Lift up the sports cap and push in half a straw, seal around it with blu tack.
Squeeze the bottle and make sure air is coming out of the top of the straw, not the sides.
FOR THE ROCKET
Draw and cut out a cardboard rocket.
Seal one end of a larger straw than the one in the bottle with sellotape.
Attach the rocket onto one side of the straw.
Place the rocket on the bottle and squeeze the bottle hard, the rocket should fly into the air.

videos.title: How to Make an Impressive 8 Layer Density Tower
videos.description:
You'll have to try this fun kids science experiment to see what happens when you layer liquids of different densities. Making an impressive 8 Layer Density Tower Experiment requires an understanding of density. Let me explain a bit - to calculate a density of an object, you would measure its mass and divide it by its volume. Pretty easy, right?
So grab liquids from around the house and start pouring them into a glass; just make sure you do it gently and follow the correct order. If you do not have anything from the list, you can skip it.
⭕ LIQUIDS ORDER FOR DENSITY TOWER:⠀
- Honey
- Marple syrup
- Milk
- Hand soap
- Water
- Rubbing Alcohol
- Vegetable oil
- Baby oil

Have you ever wondered about the density difference between liquids and solids? In this experiment, you will have a chance to explore that. After you poured eight layers of liquids, drop some objects in your glass and watch how deep they would go. Every object will get stuck at a level that has a similar density to its own. We tested steel screw, marbles, raisins, peanuts and ping pong ball.

videos.title: Egg Magic Trick - How to Fold an Egg
videos.description:
#Shorts Today we are taking our yesterday's egg science experiment a bit further. This time we dissolved an empty eggshell! We blew out the egg's insides through a small hole and let the eggshell sit in the vinegar for a day (it could take longer). We ended up with a naked egg membrane that looks like an egg, but you can actually fold it. If you bounce it from one hand to another, the membrane will suck in the air back and it again will look like an egg. This looks like a magic trick, doesn't it? In fact, I remember seeing a magician performing it once
 #TheDadLab #eggs #eastereggs #scienceexperiments #eggshell

videos.title: Let's Crack an Egg Underwater | Simple Science Experiment with Eggs
videos.description:
#Shorts Most of us are used to seeing a flat fried egg. But if you crack an egg underwater, you can notice that the yolk has sort of a spherical shape. It would be amazing to test this while swimming in the actual sea somewhere hot, but here we are doing it at home in a big bowl. If a poached egg is your thing, you probably have done this experiment before, but now ask your friends what shape they think the yolk is and let them play around with it in a jar full of water.
