videos.title: Magnetic Field Science Experiment for Kids
videos.description:
Have you ever wondered how magnets work?
Magnetic fields exert force on other magnetic materials. This force is what causes the magnet to stick to the fridge or the magnet to stick to the paper clips.
In this magnetic field science experiment for kids, you will be able to see how these forces look and how magnetic field lines behave.
It is always fun to play with magnets. We added iron filings to a bottle of shampoo to see the magnetic field. If you move a magnet over the bottle and look closely, you notice the outline of magnetic force created by iron filings.

videos.title: Finding Centre of the Mass of a Ruler | Simple Science
videos.description:
We are trying a fun way to find the centre of the mass of a ruler. If you hold your index fingers in front of you, put a ruler on top of them and start moving your hands towards each other, your fingers end up right at the unique point where the ruler's mass is centred. We added weight on one side to make it more challenging, and then we tried moving fingers at different speeds and placing fingers at the asymmetrical position. But every time we fingers meet right under the centre of the mass of the ruler. How does it work? The finger that is closer to the centre of the mass carries more weight and friction increases letting the other finger come closer. Then the same thing is happening with the second finger, which allows the first finger to slide.
#TheDadLab #scienceisfun #scienceforkids

videos.title: Hot Water Density Experiment
videos.description:
This simple density science experiment starts with placing two glasses with yellow water on top of two glasses with blue water.  When we remove cards that separate coloured water, colours on the right do not mix, but they do mix quickly on the left. Magic secret hies in the temperature of the water. Hot water is less dense than cold water, so it rises to the top as oil would. But in case hot water is already on top, it does not move anywhere, and colours do not mix

videos.title: Raw Eggs Science | Learning about Inertia
videos.description:
You probably know that by spinning an egg, you can find out if it is raw or hard-boiled. But did you know that if you stop a spinning raw egg for a second with your finger and release it, it continues spinning for a little bit? A raw egg has two main parts: a hard shell and the liquid inside. So when we start turning the egg, the inner part does not want to move, it resists that change, making it challenging to begin spinning the egg. The same thing is happening when we are stoping the egg: we are stoping the shell, and the liquid inside keeps on turning. This resistance to change of movement is called Inertia!
#TheDadLab #scienceexperiment #scienceforkids

videos.title: How to Make Magnetic Slime
videos.description:
Do your kids love slime? Mine do now! I bet you've seen the trend going around of all these variations of homemade slime with the latest craze - magnetic slime.  My boys love magnetic slime because it's so much more interactive than regular slime. It's a great way to teach kids about magnetism while having fun at the same time. Magnetic slime is made by adding iron filings to any recipe of homemade gooey slimes. We made slime by mixing Elmer's (PVA) glue, shaving gel and liquid laundry detergent. But you can add iron filings to any recipe that worked for you. Some of you said that your liquid laundry detergent did not produce slime, which could be the case because different brands use different ingredients. Your best bet is to replace detergent with a contact lens solution. It is important to say that our "magnetic slime" is not magnetic by itself, which means it will not stick to metal things. But iron filings make it react to magnets, so you need a powerful magnet to enjoy this slime in full.

videos.title: How to Blow a Balloon Underwater | Simple Science Experiment
videos.description:
This experiment looks simple, but a lot of science is involved here. We are making a chemical reaction to change the combined density of our bottle with a balloon. That makes it float to the top with all the heavy weight of paperclips. 

What you need:
• A small bottle
• Paperclips and (small nuts or pebbles)
• Baking Soda
• Funnel (optional)
• Teaspoon
• Balloon
• Vinegar
• Pipette
• Vase or tall glass
• Water
Instructions:
1. Take a small bottle, fill it with some paper clips, small nuts or pebbles (high density
materials), to make it heavy.
2. Add half a teaspoon of baking soda into the bottle. You might need to use a small
funnel.
3. Use a pipette to put about 3 squirts of vinegar into the balloon.
4. Wrap the balloon around the lip of the bottle, but make sure
that the vinegar does not go into the bottle.
5. Take a vase or tall glass and fill it with water.
6. Carefully grab the bottle by the neck, making sure that the balloon0
is hanging down by its side.
7. Drop it into the water.
8. What happens? Does the bottle go to the bottom? Does it stay there?

The Science Explained:
This experiment looks simple, but a lot of science is involved here. Can you see the bubbles? Those bubbles are filled with a gas called Carbon dioxide (CO₂), a substance that was created when we mixed the vinegar and baking soda. The combined density of the contraption we made is higher than that of the water, so it sinks to the bottom at first. After the chemical reaction takes place, created CO₂ decreases the density of
the contraption to a point lower than that of the water, so it floats to the top

videos.title: Does an orange float or sink? Kids Density Science Experiment
videos.description:
Have you ever wondered if an orange would float or sink? It turns out that this is a question that many people ask, and the answer may surprise you. It turns out that not all materials float on water! How does density come into play? Density is a measure of how tightly atoms are packed in a given material. The more tightly packed the atoms are, the higher the density of the material. Materials with high densities will have more mass per unit volume than those with low densities.

videos.title: How To Make Instant Ice Science Experiment | Simple Science
videos.description:
How cool is this instant ice experiment? But let me be honest. This experiment looks simple, but it is not! The idea isn't new, and we wanted to try it for a while because we did not need a lot to make this experiment: just a bottle of water, an ice cube and a freezer. But what they usually fail to mention is that the most crucial ingredient for the project's success is patience! 
It took us a few weeks to film this experiment!
Where do I start? Ok. So only clean bottled water from the shop would work. Unfortunately, you can't fill an empty plastic bottle with water if you want to experiment to work. 
Then you have to be very precise with the timing. For example, if you do not hold the bottle in the freezer for long enough, the water will not turn into ice when you pour it on top of an ice cube. But then again, a bit too long - and you end up with ice in the bottle. 
A piece of advice for those brave enough to take on the challenge, if your water bottle froze once, you cannot defrost it and use it again - the experiment will not work. We made that conclusion after quite a few tries.
When you have done everything right, and you got a perfect almost iced water bottle, you have to be very careful not to shake it or bang it; otherwise, it will turn into ice all of a sudden. If you are pouring water into a glass, make sure the glass is spotlessly clean. A piece of dust could make water start turning into the ice.
That is it! It takes a lot of tries to make it work. I think this is a great experiment for older children who can go through the process of discovery independently. But if you are a parent or a teacher and want to show something cool quickly to children, this experiment has a low success rate of going right at your first try.
Anyway, the experiment looks impressive, and even though it took us a while, I am happy we have tried it.

videos.title: 5 DIY Games to Practice Addition | Fun Math for Children
videos.description:
Math is part of the STEAM system - Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics! It is essential to teach all five of them. And the best way to engage with children is to turn lessons into a game. Leave a comment down below which part of STEAM your children are the most excited about!

⭕️ Math can be a hands-on activity! When we make it more tactile, it makes it easier for kids to learn. Filling up rubber gloves with rice, we make a new set of hands that the kids can count on. This is a great way to introduce addition and counting because the answer is visual. It’s also great for subtraction!

⭕️ Pin it Down. This addition game is a great start to doing sums in the head. All the answers are right there- you just have to do the work to find the right one! It’s really satisfying when you pin the equation to the right answer.

⭕️ Math Garage. I love this addition game because it shows how many different answers there can be to the same question. This is great for kids that are active and love to solve puzzles, or just love cars!

⭕️ Is it time to pick apples yet? This addition activity shows a whole math formula altogether. The apples on our math tree also help count, so you can double-check the answer you came up with. This one is also great for getting fast sums.

⭕️ The Addition Machine. Do you like my addition machine? I find because you can write your own numbers, this one is the most versatile of the bunch.

videos.title: Candle Under Glass Science Experiment for Halloween
videos.description:
This Halloween, try the classic science experiment with the candle under a glass with a vampire twist! This simple spooky science experiment is perfect for the holiday season! If you little scientist asks why the vampire sucked all the blood (coloured water), here is a simple explanation.
The candle is heating the air inside the glass; it expands and gets out (you can see air bubbles when you place the glass in water). When the candle goes out, the air inside starts cooling down and shrink back to its original volume. Water blocks the way for air to come in, so air pressure outside pushes on it, causing it to go into the glass.

videos.title: How to Make Melting Snowman Experiment | Christmas Science
videos.description:
Let me show you how to make a melting snowman experiment that is both simple and festive. The first step is to mix one glass of baking soda with 1 tbsp of salt, 2 tbsp of hand wash and 4 tbsp of water. Next, mould three balls and stack them. videos.title: Simple Christmas Science Experiment
videos.description:
Here is one of the most colourful science experiments you can try at Christmas. 
 MATERIALS:⠀
- Baking soda⠀
- Food colouring
- Water
- Ice tray
- Vinegar
- Hand wash
 INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Add a few drops of food colouring to baking soda, add a little bit of water and mix
(2) Repeat with different colours.⠀
(3) Add the mixtures to your ice tray⠀
(4) Freeze until solid
(5) Lay them out in a deep bowl
(6) Add hand wash to vinegar and mix
(7) Pour the mixture over the frozen shapes and watch them fizz
(: Mix up the foam to create colourful art
 SCIENCE EXPLANATION
When we mix vinegar and baking soda, they react and produce a gas - carbon dioxide. We added soap into the mix. So the gas blows bubbles, creating a lot of foam.

videos.title: Tooth Decay Experiment with Eggs and Drinks | Why We Brush Teeth
videos.description:
This experiment is designed to show the effects of different liquids on teeth. We used eggs because similar to teeth, eggshells contain calcium compounds. We prepared 4 glasses with 4 different liquids: cherry juice drink, vinegar, coffee and blackcurrant juice drink. We dropped four eggs into each glass and left them there for 24 hours to conduct the experiment. All drinks did not visibly damage eggs but coloured them into different colours. Later we tried to clean them using toothpaste, but you can still see some discolourization even after brushing. On the other hand, vinegar has weakened the shell, making it soft. No toothpaste will help to restore that effect!
Anyway, we encourage you to try the same experiment with the drinks you have at home to see what effect they have on teeth (eggs) and we hope this would motivate more vigorous teeth brushing (:

videos.title: Diving Jellyfish in a Bottle | DIY Science Experiment
videos.description:
Today, we are making a simple experiment with diving jellyfish in a bottle. It is also called a bottle diver.

⭕ MATERIALS:⠀
- Paper straw
- Paper clip
- Empty plastic bottle
- String
- Water
- Scissors
- Permanent markers

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:⠀
(1) Cut about two inches long piece of paper straw, colour it with a permanent marker.
(2) Thread a string through the straw and fold it in half.
(3) Slide the straw over a paperclip so that two ends of a paper clip go inside two ends of the straw
(4) Fill a plastic bottle with water.
(5) Put your jellyfish in and close the cap.
(6) Now squeeze the bottle to make the jellyfish sink and release to make him float again!

⭕ SCIENCE EXPLAINED
This experiment is about density. When we squeeze the bottle, we compress the air inside the straw. The air would keep the same mass, but now it would take up less volume, making it more dense, so the jellyfish sinks.

#TheDadLab #kidsscience #scienceforkids

videos.title: Upside-Down Water Glass | Viral TikTok Science Experiments
videos.description:
Here is another fake viral science experiment that was floating online for a while. Can we really turn a glass upside down so that water stays in the glass? 
This trick uses a bit of real science, making it harder to understand where the real science finishes and the fake one begins. 
Air molecules are constantly pushing into things creating a pressure of about 1 kg per square centimetre. That is enough pressure to hold a card under the water glass in place. The weight of water in my glass is only around 0.1 kg and there is no air pressure in the glass. So the upwards air pressure is much greater than the pressure of the water pushing down – keeping the water in the cup. In theory, water could stay in a glass even without a card. However, in practice, it's impossible to achieve. Water surface tension is not enough to stabilize the surface when the card is removed. A tiny ripple in the surface of the water makes the water pour down.
The secret of this demonstration is hiding in a special glass that you could get from any magician shop. 
This glass makes this fake science experiment look cool, but this is just a magic trick - not science!
There you have it, another misleading science experiment!
Hit the follow to avoid being deceived again.

videos.title: This Hack Turns Any Phone into a Black Light to Spot Microbes | Fake Science
videos.description:
Who would want to have millions of viruses and bacteria scattered around their bathroom? Not me! By a happy chance, it looks like there is a simple trick to check for microbes, and all you need is a phone with a flashlight and a bit of fake science. Viral videos claim that everyone can make blacklight by just colouring a flashlight with Sharpies. Blacklight is invisible to the human eye. But it can be absorbed by certain substances that contain phosphors, which convert ultraviolet light into glowing light. Body fluids are those substances as well as neon markers. This "DIY blacklight" does make neon markers glow in the dark, but just a little bit and only when you are very close. I could not make any microbes glow with it at all. When I used a real blacklight torch (you can see that clip at the very beginning of my video), all my marks were brightly glowing in the dark. All in all, this video includes a fake blacklight torch and fake viruses and bacteria.
Follow for more exposed fake science experiments!

videos.title: CLEAR Coca Cola with Vitamin C Trick Exposed
videos.description:
Let’s debunk another fake science experiment! This time we’ll be looking at whether Vitamin C can turn coke transparent. In viral videos, it appears this is true, but this is a lie! They’ve swapped out the coke for iodine water, which is a similar colour to coke. To make Iodine water, you need to add about 1 tbsp of Iodine to half a litre of water. When you add half of a tsp of vitamin c, it splits the Iodine molecules into colourless ions resulting in the brown liquid changing into a clear one!
But we can use real science to make the colour return by adding six tbsp of hydrogen peroxide and one scoop of starch. I added a bit of water to the glass just to make it easier to mix.
Three colourless Iodine ions combine with one starch molecule, which returns them to their original colour.
When you add Vitamin C to authentic coke, the chemical reaction is completely different and similar to when you put mentos in!
This science experiment is fake!
Hit follow to see me debunk more fake science experiments!

videos.title: Flying Mask with Candle Experiment Exposed
videos.description:
You may have seen this flying mask experiment floating around the internet. But, can a candle make a mask fly? In this video, we are testing this out by recreating the experiment. 
We all know how hot air balloons work. This experiment is a similar concept but on a smaller scale. A flame will heat the air molecules around it. Science tells us that hot air rises because it becomes less dense. The mask acts as the hot air balloon, trapping the hot air inside and lifting the mask. Even if a small candle like this could generate enough heat to lift the weight of this surgical mask and candle itself, the mask isn’t enclosed enough, and the material allows air to pass through it. 
This flying mask experiment is fake!
Follow along to see me debunk more fake science experiments!

videos.title: Dancing Foil | Cool Electricity Science Experiment
videos.description:
Are your kids bored of watching the same old magic tricks from a magician? Well, why not invite them to a science party instead! Here we make our own magic with dancing foil. When rubbing a balloon on wool, a charge known as static electricity is created. This charge makes foil react. So here is a fun, exciting way to make your foil jump, pop, dance and be the life of the party!

⭕MATERIALS:
- Empty water bottle
- Aluminium foil
- Balloons
- Hat (You could also use other wool or nylon items or your own hair!)

⭕INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Taking your sheet of foil, tear it into small pieces and roll them into tiny balls.
(2) Once you have enough balls, place them inside the empty water bottle and twist the cap back on.
(3) Next, blow up your balloons and tie the end.
(4) Rub your balloon onto the wool hat for around 30 seconds.
(5) Now, in one hand hold your bottle on its side. In the other hand, wave the balloon underneath the bottle and watch the foil balls dance around!

videos.title: Can You Really Turn Coal Into Diamonds with Peanut Butter
videos.description:
Do you think freezing a peanut butter covered piece of coal creates a diamond? Check out this video to find out! 
Diamonds form in the Earth’s mantle under extreme heat and pressure. The diamonds are then delivered to the Earth’s surface through rare volcanic eruptions, which carry some of the Earth’s mantle to the surface.
We are not recreating this process by covering coal in peanut butter and freezing for 24 hours!
It’s easy to fake this experiment by swapping out the piece of coal for a piece of quartz in a mixture of flour & black paint, and peanut butter. So, when we wash away the first layer with warm water, it reveals a piece of quartz. You can, in fact, hide anything in this fake piece of coal - a toy, a key or an engagement ring (this could be a pretty creative marriage proposal).
But, when we wash the genuine piece of coal coated in peanut butter and frozen, there is no diamond, and if we break it open, we can see its coal throughout! 
This experiment is fake!
Hit follow for more fake science experiments.

videos.title: How to Make Paper Panpipes | Musical Instruments Crafts
videos.description:
Let’s brighten up the day with this DIY rainbow instrument and a joyful jingle to play for all! The panpipes are a woodwind instrument that has brought happiness all around, even back to ancient greek when they were first invented. These instruments are usually made from bamboo or reeds, but today you can make your own using materials you already have at home. We make ours into a vibrant rainbow assortment, but feel free to create your own patterns with any colours you like. Then, simply blow into the pipes to hear a merry melody!

⭕MATERIALS:
- 5 sheets of paper in rainbow colours (you can also use any other colours you have)
- Scissors
- Pen
- Glue
- Cardstock 

⭕INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) First, take your coloured paper and cut them into rectangles. Make sure every piece is bigger than the last until you have all different sizes.
(1a) Remember to keep hold of the offcuts.
(2) Use the pen to help roll the paper around it. Keep in mind that tubes with smaller diameters make louder sounds.
(3) Secure the paper together using glue.
(4) Once dry, slide the paper off of the pen. Now you have your first pipe.
(5) Repeat this process with the remaining coloured paper until you have 7 pipes in different sizes.
(6) Leaving your pipes to one side, take each colour of offcut paper and make a circle that is big enough to fit over the end of each pipe. 
 (6a) A helpful tip is to draw around the top of the pen lid, so it is a perfect size.
(7) Glue each circle to the bottom of the correct colour.
(8) Next, cut a strip of cardstock big enough to fit nicely around all seven pipes.
(9) Arrange the pipes into size order and glue a strip of card around all of the pipes.
(10) Once dried, you now have a bright and cheerful instrument. Gently blow into the open end of each pipe to play!

videos.title: Electric Play Dough Science Experiments
videos.description:
Playdough doesn’t have to just be for little kids. Here is a fun way for the older ones to join in. From measuring and mixing the dough to making a light glow, this experiment is sure to be engaging and exciting for all. 

⭕MATERIALS:
- Flour (160g)
- Salt (160g)
- Water (230ml)
- Vegetable Oil (1 tbsp)
- Lemon Juice
- Food Colouring (optional)
- Component LED
- 9v Battery Pack
- 2 Battery Cables (Double-end alligator clips) 

⭕INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) First, we need to make the dough. In a bowl, mix the flour, salt, water, oil and lemon juice together until you max a dough.
(2) Split the dough into 2 even pieces. Here you can add your food colouring if preferred. 
(3) When your dough is ready, take a small section of each piece and roll them into small balls.
(4) Add the longer wire to one ball of the dough and the shorter wire to the other. 
(5) Now taking your first cable, attach one clip to the + side of your battery.
(6) With your second cable, attach one clip to the - side of your battery.
(7) Holding the opposite clips, press them onto your dough balls and watch the LED light up.
(7a) You must make sure that the + side is touching the dough with the longer LED leg and the - is touching the shorter leg.
(8) Now you can test out different kinds of circuits. Here we are using 3 balls of dough and 2 LEDs. The light does not shine as bright with just one battery pack. So, we have added a second one, attaching them together + to -, then adding the clips as before. 
(9) Next we have rolled the dough to make 2 long shapes and have added 3 LEDs. 
What other shapes and circuits can you make?

⭕SCIENCE EXPLAINED:
So how does this work? Salted playdough conducts electricity. The LED bridges the gap between + and - and the light starts to shine. This is known as a series circuit. When rolling out the playdough into 2 longer shapes side by side, this allows electricity to pass through all the LEDs at the same time. This is known as a parallel circuit. The LED will only light up if the circuit is connected correctly. 
#TheDadLab #kidsscience #scienceexperiments

videos.title: How to Make a Paper Fidget | Cool Paper Crafts
videos.description:
Did you know you can make paper move and twist? Here is a fun paper folding craft that will keep little hands busy for ages. The art of folding paper into new and cool things is a Japanese tradition that has grown into a worldwide hobby. It is brilliant for practising those fine motor skills and can help with focusing too. What’s even better is that at the end of it you have your very own craft that changes faces with every twist. You’ll be mesmerised by its kaleidoscope pattern! 

⭕Materials:
- 2 pieces of coloured paper (any colour you like)
- Scissors

⭕Instructions:
(1) Take your first piece of coloured paper and fold one corner to the opposite side and cut off the remaining so you have a square. 
(2) Take the square and fold in half, then cut these into 2 separate rectangles. Repeat this until you have 4 small squares altogether.
(3) Taking one square, fold a corner to meet the other diagonally, unfold and repeat on the other side.
(4) Next, fold each corner into the middle X crease.
(5) Unfold, then refold in half to make a rectangle and unfold again.
(6) Fold both sides of the paper into the middle crease. 
(7) Following the groove of the creases, push the two sides of the paper inwards to make a triangle.
(8) Fold all 4 corners of the triangle into the centre, until you have a small square.
(9) Repeat this with each piece of paper so you have 8 squares.
(10) Slightly unfold each one so the paper sits neatly inside one another. 
(11) Slowly, close up the chain of paper you have made. Then unfold the piece on each end.
(12) Attach the two end pieces together to make a circle. Now you can twist your kaleidoscope papercraft!

videos.title: How To Make a Light Bulb at Home | Cool Electricity Science Experiment
videos.description:
Any mini Thomas Edison’s out there? Another everyday item that we tend to overlook is the lightbulb. How do we get light from flipping on a switch? Well, why not create your own at home and learn exactly how they work. 

⭕MATERIALS:
- Small glass (around 1.50z)
- 2 battery cables (with double-end clips)
- Electrical tape
- Scissors
- Glass jar
- 2 D batteries
- Copper wire

⭕INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Taking the first battery cable, tape it to the bottom of the glass. Make sure not to tape the clip as we will need this later.
(2) Repeat this with the second battery cable and leave the glass upside down.
(3) Now take the 2 batteries, tape them together + to - side.
(4) Cut a small strip of copper wire and place it in between the 2 clips that are secured to the small glass. 
(5) Place the large glass jar over the smaller one. Make sure the other end of the wires is outside of the glass.
(6) Touch both clips to the ends of the D batteries and watch the wire glow.

⭕SCIENCE EXPLAINED:
When a light switch is turned on, electricity is sent from a power source to heat a filament. The batteries act as a source of power in which the electricity is sent through the cables and to the copper wire. This then heats the wire up until a glow is produced. Now you have made another simple circuit!

videos.title: DIY Colour Pencil Xylophone | Musical Instruments Crafts
videos.description:
Here is a fun way to reuse old or broken items from around the house and create something new and wonderful. This DIY is known as upcycling and it’s a fantastic way for parents and children to spend some time together as they make something fun. We are using old colouring pencils (but any sort of pencil will do) and we’ll make a xylophone for all the family to play with. Even your baby sibling will be drawn to this colourful craft and enjoy banging on the keys!

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Scissors
- 2 wooden skewers
- 2 beads or balls
- Pencil sharpener
- Coloured pencils (or normal pencils)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Firstly, using your scissors, cut the cardboard into 4 rectangles that will create a trapezium shape when put together.
 (1a) For reference, the longer sides should be equal to one another. The right-hand side should be smaller than the equal-sized rectangles and the left-hand side should be the smallest.
(2) Once you have all 4 sides, take the two longer equal sides and make triangular incisions on the parallel edge of each other. This is where the pencils will rest.
(3) Next, cut out slots about halfway into each cardboard piece for them to all interlock together. 
 (3a) See how we have done it in the video. You could also ask an adult for help on this bit!
(4) Place all the pieces together, making sure that the ridges for the pencils are facing upwards. Now you have your base in the shape of a trapezium
(5) Place this to one side and take your 2 wooden skewers or rods. Place the balls or beads onto the end of each skewer. These will be your xylophone sticks (also known as mallets)
(6) Make sure your pencils are different lengths and place them in their allotted spaces
(7) Now your xylophone is complete, take your sticks and play a tune!

videos.title: How to Build a Simple Electric Motor | Simple Science
videos.description:
Lots of everyday items use motors: cars, fridges, washing machines, fans and vacuum cleaners. This doesn’t sound too exciting, but that is because we don’t see them in action. So here is a fun way to create your own motor and watch how a wire with electrical current acts in a magnetic field.

⭕ MATERIALS:
- AA battery
- 2 paper clips
- Tape 
- Copper wire
- Pen
- Small magnet

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Taking your paper clips, fold them out to make a small hole in the middle.
(2) With the first paper clip, take one hooked end and secure it to the top of the battery using tape.
(3) Repeat this with the second paper clip. Make sure the other hooked ends are facing the same direction.
(4) Place this to one side. Then take your pen and copper wire. Wrap the wire around the pen about ten times to make a coil. 
(5) After sliding the coiled wire of the pen, twist each end around to tighten and secure it. Make sure to leave a small piece of wire out on each side.
(6) Taking your battery, carefully place each end of the wire through the hole in the paper clips.
(7) Set this down and place your magnet on top of the battery but underneath the copper wire. Now watch your mini motor spin into action!

⭕ SCIENCE EXPLAINED:
The paper clips and wire created an electrical circuit that can carry current. Current flows from the negative terminal of the battery, through the circuit, to the positive terminal of the battery. The current creates a magnetic field, which interacts with a magnetic field coming from a magnet underneath and makes out motor spin.

⭕ Materials:

⭕ Instructions:

videos.title: How Do You Make a Fidget With Just Paper
videos.description:
If you're looking for a fun and fidgety way to pass the time, try making a fidget with just paper. There are many different ways to create your own fidget, so find one that you enjoy!
⭕ Materials:
- Tone-toned origami paper 
- Ruler
- Pencil
- Scissors
- Glue

⭕ Instructions: 
(1) Measure and draw the lines as shown.
(2) Cut out each strip.
(3) Attach each piece to one another to make one long piece at gets smaller in size.
(4) Fold the corner to make a triangle. Then continue folding triangles, each time flipping the paper to the other side. 
(5) Keep folding in this square formation until a pyramid is formed.
(6) Cut off the excess
(7) Now, pulling apart, starting from the bottom, twist each triangle in on itself to secure it in place.
(8) When complete, you can now twist and spin your new fidget toy!

videos.title: Melted Crayon Rocks | Simple DIY Gift Ideas
videos.description:
There is always something to celebrate, whether it’s father’s day, a birthday or even Christmas! It’s not always easy to buy a present after a present. videos.title: Floating Dry Ice Experiment
videos.description:
What happens when dry ice is added to a shallow amount of water? In this experiment, you can test this out for yourself. Using water and dry ice, watch the reactions of the different elements. Does the ice move? What does the water look like? Is it foggy or smoky? To further extend this experiment, you can also make a bottle cap float like a boat!

⭕ Materials:
- Pan or tray
- Water
- Food colouring
- Dry Ice

⭕ Instructions: 
(1) Pour the water into the tray.
(2) Add the food colouring and give it a stir
(3) Carefully add the dry ice and watch the reaction!

For an extension experiment, make a small hole in the side of the bottle cap. Add your small piece of dry ice and cover with tape. Squirt the water from the syringe into the bottle cap and place it onto the tray of water.

#TheDadLab #scienceteacher #scienceexperiment
Dry ice should ALWAYS be handled with gloves, and eye protection must be worn. Never place dry ice in airtight containers. Only use in an area with proper ventilation.

videos.title: DIY Cardboard Game Craft Idea
videos.description:
Shoot and score with your very own air hockey table! Now you can bring your favourite arcade game into the comfort of your own home. Using the power of your hands and elastic bands, try to get all of your pucks onto the opposing side to win!

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Protractor 
- Pen
- Scissors
- Glue stick
- Tape
- 2 pieces of coloured card
- Ruler
- Hot glue gun & glue
- Gimlet
- 2 elastic bands
- 4 paper clips

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Firstly, use your protractor to measure and cut out 3 equal circles.
(2) Glue them together, then secure them with tape.
(3) Cut out 2 circles of the coloured card to glue to the top and bottom of the puck.
(4) Repeat this step until you have 3 pucks in one colour and 3 pucks in a different colour.
(5) With a rectangular sheet of cardboard, draw a line straight through the middle. 
(6) Glue your 2 different coloured cards onto the cardboard.
(7) Take a strip of cardboard (the same length as the board) and cut out a square big enough to fit the pucks through.
(8) Use the hot glue gun to attach this to the board, standing up.
(9) Glue pieces of cardboard along each side of the board.
(10) Now you can add some designs using the coloured card!
(11) Next, make a hole on either end of the board. Repeat on the other side.
(12) Thread your elastic band onto a paper clip, then feed it through one of the holes and out the other end. 
(13) Attach the next paper clip to create a slingshot.
(14) Now add your pucks and try to hit them all onto the opposing side!

videos.title: Dipping Dandelion in Water | Outdoor Science Experiment
videos.description:
This simple experiment with dandelion is just mind-blowing. Have you ever thought about what would happen with dandelion if it gets put underwater? I tested that, and it repelled water and stayed dry! 
Because each dandelion seed is attached to loads of feathery bristles that cannot pierce the surface tension of water. That creates an air bubble around our dandelion, and that is what keeps our flower dry.
Go out and try it yourself!

videos.title: Melted Crayon Butterfly Craft
videos.description:
Symmetry is all around us from nature to shapes and even our own reflections in mirrors and windows. Learning about symmetry with children helps them to understand balance and teaches them about the patterns of the world. One common symmetrical shape is a butterfly. Both of their beautiful, bright wings reflect the same pattern. Here is a fun, creative craft to help little ones explore symmetry!

⭕ Materials:
- Paper
- Pencil
- Butterfly silhouette
- Crayons
- Pencil sharpener
- Iron
- Paper towels
- Scissors

⭕ Instructions:
(1) First, fold your paper in half and draw the outline of the butterfly. You do not have to draw the whole outline, only half.
(2) Next, shave your crayons onto the paper. Spread the crayon into fun, colourful patterns.
(3) Fold the paper in half, making sure the crayons are on the inside.
(4) Place a paper towel on top and press with an iron
(5) Unfold the paper to reveal your beautiful symmetry butterfly.
(6) Once cooled, cut around the outline.

videos.title: How to Straighten an Old Bent Nail with Water, Salt and Battery | Fake Science
videos.description:
Can a bent nail straighten when put in salty water with a battery?
Despite how it appears, the battery and salt have no effect here. What's crucial is the material of the nail and the temperature of the water; this is where science comes in.
The nail is made out of Nitinol - an alloy of nickel and titanium. Nitinol is also known as memory metal as it remembers its previous form. When exposed to 500 degrees Celsius for 5 minutes, the atoms inside Nitinol become fixed in their position. Once cooled to room temperature Nitinol can be bent out of shape and will remain deformed; however, if the metal is heated again, with hot water, for example, it will return to its original form, as seen in the video with the nail and the paper clip.
This experiment is deceiving, but there is the real science behind it.
Hit follow to avoid being fooled again!
#TheDadLab #scienceexperiment #dontbefooled

videos.title: How to make a Marble Maze | DIY Cardboard Games
videos.description:
Tilt the board to move the marble! Can you make it through the labyrinth? Here is how to make your own marble maze game. Make as many different boards and mazes as you like, for hours of fun!

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Hot glue gun & glue
- Ruler
- Pencil 
- Tape
- Coloured card
- Pen
- Marble

⭕ Instructions:
(1) To make your board, start with a square piece of cardboard and glue boarders around each edge.
(2) Next, glue 3 small pieces of cardboard together and secure them to the board. Repeat this until you have 3 plinths.
(3) With another piece of cardboard, measure 4, 3cm rectangles and use the ruler to score them. 
(4) Fold them to make a square and tape it secure.
(5) Repeat step 3 and 4, then glue them on either side of the board.
(6) Taking another square piece of cardboard, glue a piece of coloured card on top. 
(7) Use a pen and a ruler to draw a maze pattern. Then add strips of cardboard to each line with hot glue. Also, make sure to cut out a small square for the marble to fall into. (You can also add details like an arrow)
(8) Now, place your maze on the board. Add the marble and try to balance your way through to find the hole.
(9) Once your marble has fallen into the hole, you can easily remove the maze and start again. You can make lots of different mazes, simple or tricky, and easily replace them on the board!

videos.title: How To Make Marble Game at Home | DIY Cardboard Loop Game
videos.description:
Does anyone else love watching cars on a track? Here is a cardboard game you can create at home, that gives the same lively, speedy fun. This moveable game will have your children switching and turning the track as fast as they can, to keep the ball moving on and on and on! 

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Pan lid or plate (something circular)
- Pen
- Scissors
- Ruler 
- Rolling Pin
- Hot glue gun & glue
- 4 Wooden dowels
- Gimlet
- Ball

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Firstly, draw around a plate or pan lid to create a circle. Then draw around a smaller one directly in the middle.
(2) Draw 2 small rectangles on either side of the circle, then cut the whole thing out. 
(3) Repeat the first step again. 
(4) Cut both circles in half, so you have 4 semi-circles. 
(5) Place those to one side and get a long piece of cardboard. Use the rolling pin to flatten it. 
(6) Cut out strips and hot glue them to each semi-circle. Make sure to include the inner side as well.
(7) Now take 4 small rectangles of cardboard and glue each one to a small wooden dowel.
(8) Arrange the cardboard into a figure of 8 and use the gimlet to make a hole in each piece. 
(9) Place the wooden dowel into each hole, to attach all the pieces together. 
(10) Use 4 more small pieces of cardboard to cover the dowels on the opposite side.
(11) Test it works, then add your ball to the track for lots of fun!

videos.title: How To Make Your Own Robot Hand | Cardboard Crafts
videos.description:
Whether you're a fan of robot movies or just watching your dad's embarrassing robot dance moves, robots bring a lot of joy into our lives. Here is a fun craft that children and dad's can make together. This cool project is sure to create lots of laughs while you make your very own robotic hand! Try it out and see what you can pick up with it! Why not make one for each hand and pretend you are in a real robot movie?

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Straws
- Elastic
- String
- Scissors
- Pen
- Ruler
- Hot glue gun and glue

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Trace and cut around your arm on a piece of cardboard
(2) Use the ruler to bend each part of the fingers
(3) With a smaller piece of cardboard, glue the strip of elastic on both sides. Then, glue this on to the arm.
(4) Next, cut your straws to fit each part of the finger and secure them to the hand with glue.
(5) Then, thread a piece of string through each of the straws on each finger.
(6) Glue the end of the string at the tip of the finger, then tie a loop at the other end of the string.
(7) Now place your hand through the elastic and attach each loop onto your fingers. Move them around, and now you have your own robotic arm! What things can you pick up?

videos.title: DIY Plastic Bottle Non Stop Heron's Fountain
videos.description:
Make your own plastic bottle Fountain that almost never stops. The best kinds of projects are ones that don't require lots of expensive materials. In fact, using recycled resources is so much better. Not just for the environment but also for imagination too!

⭕ Materials:
- Empty water bottles x3
- Soldering iron
- Hot glue gun
- Straws
- Pen or marker
- Scissors
- Bottle caps
- Coloured water (water and food colouring)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) With your first water bottle, carefully use a soldering iron to make 2 holes on either end.
(2) Thread one straw through the hole and secure it with the hot glue gun. Repeat with the second straw, making sure not to push it all the way into the bottle.
(3) Take your second bottle and use the pen to mark where to cut. Use a soldering iron to make identical holes on both sides of the bottle.
(4) Next, make another small hole on one side.
(5) Cut the second straw and thread the second bottle onto both straws.
(6) Then, take a third straw and thread it through the third hole.
(7) With the last bottle, cut it about a quarter of the way down, then use a soldering iron to make 2 holes in the bottle cap.
(8) Thread this onto the straws and secure it with the hot glue gun.
(9) Next, cut one of the straws to become shorter and screw the remainder of the bottle back onto the cap.
(10) Now, glue two bottle caps onto the bottom to make a stand.
(11) When complete, pour some coloured water into the top and watch what happens. What if you turn it upside down?

videos.title: TOP 5 Dry Ice Experiments Compilation
videos.description:
If you’re looking for some science activities that will blow your mind, then look no further. Here are some super fun and cool experiments using dry ice, that will certainly have your friends' mouths hanging open with surprise. Dry ice is carbon dioxide (CO2) in a solid form. Yes, it is basically frozen gas. But unlike normal, ‘wet’ ice, when it begins to melt, it doesn’t turn into water or liquid. Instead, dry ice turns to gas, which gives a foggy effect. You may have seen it used before in theatres and restaurants! But here we will show you a few different ways you can use it at home in these exciting experiments. Even though it sounds very interesting, dry ice can sometimes be dangerous. Please make sure that you are correctly handling it by wearing gloves to protect your skin. Also, remember to never eat it! But now, back to the fun!

⭕ Dry Ice Smoke  (Let’s make cold smoke!)
⭕ Floating Dry Ice  (A fun floating experiment)
⭕ Dry Ice Bubbles  (A simple bubbly activity)
⭕ Fire and Ice Experiment   (Watch dry ice react to fire)
⭕ Giant Dry Ice Bubble  (Make a giant bubble)

#TheDadLab #scienceiscool #scienceexperiments #dryice
Dry ice should ALWAYS be handled with gloves, and eye protection must be worn. Never place dry ice in airtight containers. Only use in an area with proper ventilation.

videos.title: How to Make Simple Balloon Boats
videos.description:
Why not have a balloon boat race? There is no need to stress, all the materials can be found in the comfort of your own home. 
⭕ Materials:
- Balloons
- Straws
- Elastic bands
- Plastic tray or container
- Bathtub filled with water

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Place your straw in the deflated balloon and secure it with an elastic band.
(2) Take your container and make a hole in one side.
(3) Insert the straw through the hole, with the balloon on the inside of the tray.
(4) Blow up your balloon, but make sure to hold the end of the straw, so you don't let the air out.
(5) Place it in the bathtub and let go! Watch it zoom around the water.

⭕ Science Explained:
When air is pushed out of a balloon through a straw, it pushes the balloon in the opposite direction. By keeping the balloon secure in a container, the force also moves it as a whole. This is why your boat is moving across the water.

videos.title: How to Make Marble Arcade Rocket Game with Cardboard
videos.description:
A trip to the arcade was always so much fun. But imagine bringing that fun into your own home! Now you can make a game to play with all the family. Turn your recycled cardboard into something much more fun and make lots of new memories with your own children. This fun DIY activity could be the start of your very own games room. Then you'll be certain to make all your friends jealous!

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Card
- Scissors
- Glue
- Gimlet
- Small wooden dowel (x2)
- Pen
- Hot glue gun and glue
- String
- Paper cup (x2)
- Stickers (optional)
- Marble

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Cut a piece of cardboard into a circle, then glue on a piece of card the same shape.
(2) Now, use your card to cut out shapes and make a picture. Here we have made a rocket.
(3) Next, glue a variety of different sized cardboard strips on, to make the board.
(4) With a new piece of rectangular cardboard, cut it into an arch shape, then add any more card decorations you would like.
(5) Next, use the gimlet to make a hole in the centre of the circular board. Then attach it to the rectangular board using 1 small wooden dowel.
(6) On one side of the board, make a square hole and use then pen to mark an X inside. Repeat this step slightly further down the board.
(7) Now, glue a long piece of cardboard underneath.
(8) Next, turn the board over. Mark and glue 2 more strips of cardboard in different directions. Add another board behind to keep them in place.
(9) Placing that to one side, now cut out some cardboard in the shape of a crescent, then glue it to a rolled cylinder of cardboard.
(10) Insert your second wooden dowel into the cardboard cylinder and attach it to the board, near the bottom.
(11) Next, cut and glue 4 circles together, make a hole in the middle and attach it to the wooden dowel. Repeat this step with the second dowel and use some hot glue to secure it.
(12) Tie your string around both of the circles, so they turn in unison.
(13) Attach 2 larger pieces of cardboard to each side of the board and a small square to the bottom.
(14) Cut 2 squares on each side of the board, in correspondence to where the ramps at the back of the board are.
(15) Cut 2 paper cups in half and attach the bottom sections underneath each hole. Here is where you can add a 'happy' and a 'sad' sticker to each.
(16) Now, add your marble to the top and use the handle to try to twist it into the correct hole. Your pinball game is ready to play!

videos.title: Frozen Water Flow Illusion and Balloon Experiment
videos.description:
Magicians are all about tricking the eye. This super cool experiment will give the illusion that flowing water has frozen in time. The water comes out so perfectly, that it doesn’t look like it’s moving at all. You’ll need only a few simple supplies, but everyone will think you are a top wizard! And if you want to be a magician that does reveal their tricks, we have explained the science behind it below!

⭕ Materials:
- Balloon
- Tape
- Water
- Bowl

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Fill your balloon with a lot of water and tie the end.
(2) Place the balloon into the bowl.
(3) Next, add tape to the balloon in a square shape, but make sure to leave a small open section in the middle.
(4) When the tape is secured, press a needle into the small square of the balloon.
(5) Watch the water flow like a fountain and then steadily trick your eyes like it’s not moving!

⭕ Science Explained:
This experiment is known as a laminar flow. The tape keeps the balloon secure and the surface even. When a hole is made in the balloon, the tape keeps it in place and allows the water to flow out in a nice stream. The flowing water moves without any disruptions, which gives the effect of it being frozen and not moving at all!
#TheDadLab #scienceexperiments #scienceisfun #sciencerules #scienceforkids #sciencecommunication #scienceproject #sciencekids

videos.title: How to Make a Cardboard Game - NO Electronics!
videos.description:
Quick! Catch that marble! Here is a fun DIY game you can make with supplies you already have at home. Some of these are leftover party supplies, but just because the party is over, doesn’t mean the fun has to stop. Instead of throwing those spare cups and skewers out, why not turn them into this entertaining game? Pop the marble in the top then try to catch it before it hits the bottom!

⭕ Materials:
- Cardboard
- Pen
- Wooden skewers
- Scissors
- Hot glue gun and glue
- Paper cup
- Tape
- Gimlet
- Pencil
- Coloured card (optional)
- Marble

⭕ Instructions:
(1) First, take a large piece of cardboard and use the pen to mark dots across it.
(2) Next, take some wooden skewers and cut them into small pieces. Poke each piece onto a dot.
(3) With a smaller piece of cardboard, cut out the shape of a games controller. Repeat this 3 times, then glue all 4 pieces together.
(4) Next, cut out 6-8 squares of cardboard and glue them all together. Then glue this to the back of the controller.
(5) Cut out 4 rectangular pieces of cardboard and glue them together. Then glue this to the bottom of a paper cup.
(6) To assemble the board, you’ll need a rectangular box. Cut one side off then tap it flat.
(7) Add in the board with the skewers to the top and fold the flap to secure it.
(8) Then add another piece of cardboard to the top and one to the bottom.
(9) Next, poke a hole into the cardboard with a paper cup attached and the controller. Then thread an old pencil through each piece.
(10) Now you can use some coloured cards to add decoration if you wish. Then your marble drop is ready!

videos.title: The Science of Popping Balloons
videos.description:
Here is a cool activity that seems to defy forces. Pushing needles and skewers into a balloon will surely make it pop? Well, not quite! Here we show you how you can insert a sharp object into a balloon without it popping! We have two different ways to show you, so make sure you take notes, so you can show all of your friends!

⭕ Materials:
- Balloons
- Tape
- Needles
- Skewers

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Blow up the balloon and tie it closed.
(2) Place some thick tape onto the balloon
(3) Then gently pierce your needle through the tape and balloon.
How many needles can you add?
(4) Blow up another balloon and tie it closed.
(5) Take a wooden skewer and insert it into the bottom of the balloon.
(6) Push it all the way through and out the top of the balloon, without it popping!

⭕ Science Explained:
Balloons pop easily when there is a quick pressure pushing into one spot. However, when adding tape to the balloon, you're also adding reinforcement to the rubber. This extra layer means the balloon won't stretch and burst as it would usually do when pressed with a needlepoint.
Similarly, by making sure you add the skewer to the thickest, less-stretched part of the balloon, there is less pressure being put on the balloon. Instead of bursting, the elasticity of the balloon's rubber allows it to stretch. So now you have unpopable balloons!

#TheDadLab #scienceexperiments #scienceisfun #sciencerules =====================================================

videos.title: Cool Volcano Science Experiment with Vinegar and Baking Soda
videos.description:
Erupting volcano science experiment is such a classic and a great one to support teaching in chemical reactions. Now we show you just how you can do it yourself, in the comfort of your own home and with recycled materials. 
⭕ Materials: 
For the Volcano
- Cardboard
- Water bottle
- Tape
- PVA glue (1 part)
- Water (5 parts)
- Paper
- Paint and brushes 
For the Lava
- Bottle
- Funnel
- Washing up liquid (1 tbsp)
- Red food colouring
- Vinegar (½ cup)
- Baking soda (½ cup) 
- Tray
⭕ Instructions:
(1) Firstly, start by taping some cardboard around the sides of the water bottle
(2) When you have your volcano shape, then mix 1 part PVA glue with 5 parts water.
(3) Next, tear some recycled paper. Dip it into the glue mixture and attach each strip to the volcano 
(4) Once your paper mache volcano is dry, use different reds, greys, browns and blacks to paint it.
(5) While leaving it to dry, take an empty bottle and gently mix washing up liquid with red food colouring and vinegar.
(6) Then add baking soda to the water bottle that is inside our volcano.
(7) Pour in your lava mixture and watch the volcano erupt!

videos.title: Easy Rabbit Paper Craft | How to Make a Rabbit Step by Step
videos.description:
This cute bunny paper craft is easy to make and only requires a few materials. Follow the step by step instructions below to make your own rabbit. 
⭕ Materials:
- Paper
- Pencil
- Scissors
- Glue
- Googly eyes (optional)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) With a coloured piece of paper, cut off a strip. Then cut the strip about a third of the way up.
(2) Next, draw and cut out shapes for the bunny ears, feet and tail.
(3) Then, roll and glue the end of the strip to the cut-out part.
(4) Glue the bunnies' ears/face to the rolled body.
(5) With the small remaining strip, roll it into a circle and glue it securely. Then attach it to the bottom of the bunny. 
(6) Here you can glue on the eyes, or you can draw them on and make a super cute bunny face!

videos.title: How to Make Ice Cream in 10 Minutes
videos.description:
Make your own ice cream in as little as 10 minutes! With only a few ingredients, you will never have to worry about not having the freezer stocked with ice creams all summer long.
⭕ Materials:
- Plastic sandwich bags
- Cream (1 cup)
- Sugar (2 tbsp) 
- Vanilla extract
- Ice
- Desert syrup or any other toppings (optional)
⭕ Instructions:
(1) Place a plastic bag into a bowl, then pour in your cream, sugar and vanilla extract.
(2) Seal the bag, then place it inside a second plastic bag.
(3) In the second bag, add lots of ice and seal shut.
(4) Next, shake the bag for 10 minutes
(5) Once the time is complete, open both bags and scoop out the ice cream. 
(6) Add any sauce or toppings you like and enjoy!

videos.title: How to Make a Paper Frog Craft
videos.description:
What do frogs do with paper? Rip-it Rip-it…
We hope you won’t rip this paper; let's craft with it instead! Here is a fun paper folding activity for all the frog fans. Using items you may already have at home, you won’t need to worry about spending a penny. That makes me very hoppy! This fun and simple craft is ribbiting enough to keep everyone entertained. Enough with the frog jokes, let’s hop into making it! 

⭕ Materials:
- Paper
- Ruler
- Scissors
- Pencil
- Glue
- Googly eyes (optional)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Firstly, use your pencil and ruler to measure out a rectangular piece of green paper.
(2) Cut 3 out of 4 of the sides, leaving a shorter side still attached.
(3) Line that top end with glue, then roll the long middle piece together.
(4) Then, roll the two smaller side pieces around and secure the glue. 
(5) Next, use the scissors to cut the excess paper into froggy feet.
(6) Attach your eyes and add a cute red or pink tongue. (Use the side of the scissors to curl the tongue)

videos.title: How To Pop a Balloon Inside A Balloon Using Sun
videos.description:
You may have seen before like someone sets grass or an object alight using a magnifying glass and the sun. But can those two things really create heat? Why not become a scientist for the day and do this fun experiment to test it out for yourself. All you need is 2 balloons, a magnifying glass and the sun! What do you think might happen? Why not write down a hypothesis like a real scientist would? Then have lots of fun trialling this super science experiment. 

⭕ Materials:
- Black balloon
- Clear balloon
- Balloon pump (optional)
- Magnifying Glass
- Sunlight 
- Black pen (optional)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) First, place the black balloon inside the clear balloon.
(2) Then, using a balloon pump, blow up the black balloon. If you don’t have a balloon pump then blow it up manually with your mouth.
(3) Tie the black balloon, then blow up the clear balloon bigger than the black one.
(4) Now, take your balloon outside on a sunny day. Hold a magnifying glass directly in the sun and point it towards your balloon. Watch what happens! 
(5) To take this experiment even further, draw a spot on the clear balloon with a black pen.
(6) Again, hold the magnifying glass in direct sunlight and point it towards the balloon and see what happens!

⭕ Science Explained:
We all know that the sun is very hot. But did you know that the colour black absorbs heat better than other colours? In this experiment, when direct sunlight hits the black balloon, it absorbs the heat which causes its bonds to weaken, and then it pops. Magnifying glass helps to focus the sunlight into a specific spot and heats up that area quicker. This can also be seen in expansion of this experiment, where the black dot absorbs the heat, making the clear balloon pop.

videos.title: Simple Floating Cup Magic Trick
videos.description:
Is it a bird? Is it a plane? No, it’s a floating, pouring drink! This spooky idea is the perfect magic trick for a Halloween party or even as a prank played on a friend. Watch as we show you how you can magically pour a drink while it floats in mid-air! Your audience won’t believe their eyes!

⭕ Materials:
- Plastic cup
- Clear (nylon) thread
- Scissors
- Hot glue gun and glue
- Coloured paper
- Paper clip
- Can of drink

⭕ Instructions:
(1) First, glue a small piece of clear thread across the inside of the cup
(2) Then, secure some coloured paper around the cup. (This will hide where the glue is)
(3) Carefully secure another piece of clear thread in the middle of the other piece. 
(4) Next, bend a paper clip into a T-shape and tie the other end of the thread in a knot around it. 
(5) Open the can of drink and secure the paper clip to its pull-tab.
 Now for the Magic:
(6) Lift the can in the air and as you begin to pour watch as the cup floats up from below.
✨ The thread attaches the can to the cup, so they will always move together. As the thread is clear, the audience are not able to see that it is there!

videos.title: Gummy Bear Simple Science Experiment for Kids

A day without science would be un-BEAR-able! So here is a sweet and simple science experiment, using those delicious gummy bears, that you can try at home, today! During this activity, children can become mini scientists and begin to make predictions about how each gummy bear will react to different variables. They can record their thoughts and then compare them to their findings. This experiment is also great for teaching osmosis (the process where water molecules move from a high concentration to a lower one). Why not give it a try today?  

⭕ Materials:
- 5 glasses
- 5 gummy bears
- Water (½ cup)
- Sugar (1 tbsp)
- Salt (1 tbsp)
- Fizzy cola drink (½ cup)
- Vinegar (½ cup)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) To set up this experiment, pour water into 3 of the glasses. 
(2) Leave the first glass to just have water in it. In the second glass, add the sugar and in the third glass, add the salt. 
(3) In the fourth glass, pour in some fizzy cola drink and in the fifth pour in the vinegar.
(4) Then, add a gummy bear into each glass.
(5) Wait for 12 hours then take a look at each gummy bear. What differences can you spot? How do they compare to a normal gummy bear?
#TheDadLab #scienceexperiment #scienceteacher #gummybears

videos.title: Edible Dinosaur Dig Excavation Activity for Toddlers
videos.description:
What did you want to be when you grew up? One thing I love about childhood is that you can pretend to be all of your dream jobs in one day. And today we are becoming palaeontologists! Set up this fun and easy activity and let your toddler dive in, digging and rescuing dinosaurs. Even young babies can give this a try and you don’t have to worry about it going into their mouths. Activities that double up as snacks are always the best kind! 

⭕ Materials:
- Jelly/gelatin mix
- Dinosaur figures
- Tray
- Bowl
- Spoon
- Old biscuits or crackers
- Tweezers/tongs
- Paintbrush

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Start by making the jelly according to the packet.
(2) Pour the gelatin mix into a tray and add in your dinosaur figures.
(3) Put the tray in the freezer until the jelly has set.
(4) Next, crush the old biscuits or crackers in a bowl with the back of a spoon.
(5) Sprinkle this on top of the jelly to hide the dinosaurs.
(6) Now it’s time to play! Brush and dig with your tongs and paintbrush to try and rescue the dinosaurs.

videos.title: Learn a Simple Magic Trick to Color Pictures Instantly
videos.description:
Here is a fun magic trick to do on a rainy day or even as a boredom buster. This trick includes crafting activities, which makes it perfect for passing the time. Turn any of your children’s artwork into a fun, entertaining magic trick. This is sure to be fun for all of the family!

⭕ Materials:
- Coloured paper
- Glue
- White paper
- Scissors
- Black Pen
- Double-sided tape
- Tape
- Plastic paper pocket

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Cut your coloured paper into a nice picture and glue together onto a sheet of white paper
(2) Flip it over and put a piece of double-sided tape along the top.
(3) Slide the picture into the plastic pocket then carefully remove the second side of the tape and stick it to the pocket. 
(4) When this is secure, flip it back over and trace the picture with a black pen. 
(5) Then, slide a second white sheet of paper into the plastic pocket.    (Make sure to leave a small section out)
(6) Next, cut a strip of tape and stick it to either side of the white paper to make a tab, and slide the remainder of the paper back into the pocket.
 Now for the Magic:
(7) Show your audience the black-and-white drawing of your picture. 
(8) Then, another piece of coloured paper, hold that in front of the plastic pocket.
✨ Here is a good time to shout some mystical words or wave your hands spookily. Then, as you pull the coloured card away, make sure you also pull onto the tab of tape. This will pull away the white paper, magically revealing a beautiful coloured picture.

videos.title: Slice a banana WITHOUT peeling it | Magic Trick Revealed
videos.description:
Are you looking for a fun twist to put on snack time? Or trying to get all the children to sit quietly while they’re eating? Why not show off your magical skills by slicing a banana before the skin is even peeled. Your children will think you’re Wonder Woman or Superman! All you need is a needle. Don’t worry, we won’t reveal your secret!

⭕ Materials:
- Banana 
- Needle

⭕ Instructions: 
(1) Show your audience an unpeeled banana
(2) Then, unpeel it to reveal it has already been sliced!
 Now for the Magic:
✨ Before you begin this trick, take a needle and make a small hole in the banana. With this hole, slowly drag the needle up and down the banana. This slices it inside the peel and without marking the skin. Repeat this step all the way along the banana so you get equal slices.

videos.title: DIY Homemade Claw Game: Bring the Fun of the Arcade to Your Home
videos.description:
Homemade Claw Game
Have you played this game at an arcade before? Sometimes it can be a bit tricky to win and it can cost a lot of money if you play it over and over again. But now there is no need to leave the arcades disappointed. Why not make your own claw game? This is a fun craft to make at home and you will always be the winner! It’s budget-friendly and uses materials that you may already find around the house. It’s great fun for everyone!

⭕ Materials: 
- Paper cups
- Scissors
- Hot glue gun and glue
- Straw
- Pencil
- Pompoms (optional)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Start by making 6 cuts into the paper cup and removing the 2 smaller sections.
(2) Fold the remaining four sections back on themselves.
(3) Flip the cup over and add a dot of hot glue into the centre. 
(4) Make a few small cuts into a plastic straw to fray the bottom and attach it to the glue.
(5) Use a pencil to make a hole in the bottom of a second paper cup.
(6) Then, feed the straw and claw-hand through.
(7) Now, hold the straw and move the cup up and down to try and catch the pompoms!

videos.title: How To Make Rubber Band Boat
videos.description:
Are you ready to make your own rubber band boats? This STEM craft is fun and engaging for children from start to finish. In less than 5 steps and with cheap resources or items you already have at home, you can make a boat that works with a propellor. Why not challenge your friends to make one too and hold a race? Who’s boat will speed across the water first?

⭕ Materials: 
- Empty bottle
- Chopsticks
- Elastic bands
- Popsicle sticks
- Hot glue gun and glue

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Secure the chopsticks to either side of the bottle using a few rubber bands.
(2) Then, add one more elastic band to the bottom of the chopsticks.
(3) Next, glue two popsicle sticks to each other with the elastic band in the middle.
(4) Twist the popsicle sticks to wind up the elastic bands. Place it into a tub and watch it propel across the water.

videos.title: Super Sweet Toddler Activity with Honey Bees
videos.description:
This super sweet activity won’t attract any bears or bees but it will keep your toddler engaged for ages! Using water and a wooden skewer children will have to carefully guide the honey into its pot. This is a great activity for practising fine motor skills and concentration. What's even better is that it's a quick and simple set up too! A win-win for both adults and children. 

⭕ Materials:
- Glass of water
- Gloss paint (orange and yellow)
- A printed image of a honey pot
- Plastic wallet
- Pipette 
- Wooden skewer

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Firstly, mix the gloss paint with the water to make a honey colour.
(2) Next, place the printed image into the plastic wallet.
(3) Carefully, place some drops of honey paint on top of the plastic wallet.
(4) Let the children use the wooden skewer to guide each drop of honey into its pot.

videos.title: How to Make Rainbow Soap Foam For Sensory Play
videos.description:
Sensory Soap Foam 
Children learn through using their senses so sensory play isn’t just about fun, it’s also teaching them lots of new things! This sensory activity lets children discover a new bubbly texture. Why not extend this play by letting them explore new colours and scents? Set this quick activity up in less than 5 steps and with items, you already have in your kitchen! So without having to break the bank or find the time you don’t have, you can let your little ones immerse in a new sensory experience. 

⭕ Materials:
- Tub
- Water
- Washing-up liquid
- Whisk
- Food colouring 
- Essential oils / extract (optional)

⭕ Instructions:
(1) Start by filling a tub halfway with water.
(2) Add the washing-up liquid and whisk until foamy.
(3) Now, add in a few drops of food colouring and whisk again.
(4) Here you can add different colours and maybe even some essential oils to give it a scent.

videos.title: Potato Battery | Free Electricity Science Experiment
videos.description:
Unleash your inner scientist with this fun and educational potato battery experiment! This DIY science experiment is perfect for curious minds wanting to learn about electricity and how it works. In this video, we'll demonstrate how to light up an LED using nothing but a potato, coins, and a few wires - a great hands-on way to understand the concept of a simple battery!
Ever wondered how to make a potato battery or how a potato can generate electricity? Join us as we delve into the fascinating world of basic physics and chemistry. This experiment uses the phosphoric acid in potatoes to trigger a reaction between copper and zinc, creating an electrical current strong enough to power an LED light.

Materials needed for this kid-friendly science experiment:
Potato
Copper coins
Zinc Washers or nails
LED light
Wires

We walk you through each step of the experiment, from inserting the coins into the potato to connecting the wires and lighting up the LED. 

This video is a part of our #TheDadLab series, where we make learning science fun and engaging. Remember, the best way to learn is by doing!

Don't forget to like, share, and subscribe for more fun and educational videos!

videos.title: Make a Baking Soda & Vinegar Powered Boat | Fun Science Experiment
videos.description:
Learn how to make a fascinating baking soda and vinegar powered boat. Get ready for a thrilling adventure as we harness the power of these household ingredients to propel a plastic bottle boat across water.
Have you ever wondered how chemical reactions can be used to create motion? This hands-on experiment is the perfect way to learn about the power of chemical reactions and enjoy a fun-filled activity with friends and family. Whether you're a curious student, a science enthusiast, or simply looking for a unique project, this tutorial will guide you step by step through the process.
Learn the science behind the reaction, the role of baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) and vinegar (acetic acid) in producing carbon dioxide gas. You'll discover how this gas buildup creates pressure inside the boat, forcing it to move forward with surprising speed and agility.

Follow along as we gather the necessary materials, which can be easily found in your house. We'll demonstrate the construction of the boat using readily available items such as a plastic bottle, and a few simple tools. Don't worry if you're new to DIY projects – our clear instructions and visual demonstrations make it accessible to everyone.

Once the boat is assembled, watch in awe as the chemical reaction ignites, propelling the boat forward while leaving a trail of fizzing bubbles in its wake. 

Unlock the wonders of chemistry, physics, and engineering as you engage in this interactive and educational activity. With our guidance, you'll not only have a blast creating your own baking soda and vinegar powered boat, but you'll also gain a deeper understanding of the scientific principles behind it.

Don't forget to hit that "Subscribe" button and turn on the notification bell to stay updated on our latest science experiments and tutorials. Join our community of curious minds and embark on this captivating journey into the world of science.

videos.title: Cool Tissue Wiggly Worm Science Experiment
videos.description:
“There’s a worm in the bottom of my garden and its name is Wiggly Woo!” Bring a cherished nursery rhyme to life by introducing simple science to your little ones. It doesn’t just have to be for little children too. This activity can be fun for all ages, with younger children watching the wiggly worms grow in water and the older children can design and create their own worms! 

⭕ Materials:
- Tissues
- Pens
- Pencil
- Tray
- Water

⭕ Instructions:
(1) First, use your pens to draw a nice design onto your tissue. 
(2) When you’re happy with your design, roll the tissue around the pencil.
(3) Push and scrunch it together so it is tight, then slide it off of the pencil.
(4) When your worms are ready, fill your tray with water.
(5) Pop them inside and watch them grow!

⭕ Science Explained:
This fun little experiment has a really quick and easy explanation too. Tissues absorb water. They have strong bonds within them, which the water clings onto. So when the tightly wound worm was placed in the water, it sucks it in which makes it expand and appear to be growing. 
#TheDadLab #kidsactivities

videos.title: DIY Coin Battery | Electricity Science Experiment
videos.description:
Dive into the fascinating world of science with everyday materials. This experiment is a thrilling educational experience that everyone can participate in. Little ones will be amazed to see an LED light up using simple items, and older kids can take part in setting up the experiment themselves!

⭕ Materials:
* Copper Coins
* Aluminum foil
* Card
* Vinegar
* Salt
* LED
* Scissors
* Sticky Tape
* Wires
* Craft stick or a spoon for stirring

⭕ Instructions:
(1) First, clean your copper coins using a solution of vinegar and salt. This will enhance the reaction in the experiment.
(2) Cut the card and aluminium foil into circular shapes that match the size of your cleaned coins.
(3) Soak the cut-out card pieces in vinegar.
(4) Assemble each soaked card piece between a copper coin and a piece of aluminium foil, creating a "coin sandwich". Stack few layers, always ensuring the order is coin-card-foil.
(5) Secure the stacks with sticky tape and connect wires to the top and bottom.
(6) Lastly, attach wires to your LED. Sit back and watch the magic happen as it lights up!

⭕ Science Explained:
This exciting experiment utilises fundamental concepts of electrochemistry and electrical circuits. When the cleaned copper coins (made of metal) and the vinegar (an acid) interact, they generate a small electric charge. This process, known as an electrochemical reaction. The aluminium foil acts as a conductor, allowing the accumulated charge to travel through the coin-card-foil stacks, powering the LED in the process. It's a hands-on, engaging way to understand how batteries work, using items you can easily find around the house.
#TheDadLab #scienceiscool

videos.title: DIY Glowing Christmas Tree Craft: Easy LED Circuit Project for the Holidays
videos.description:
Ready to light up the holiday season with a bit of science magic? Gather around! We're about to create a twinkling Christmas tree with a simple circuit and a dash of creativity. Let's transform paper into a glowing masterpiece!

⭕ MATERIALS:
Christmas Tree Drawing or a print
Foil tape
Coin cell battery
LED light

⭕ INSTRUCTIONS:
(1) Draw or print a Christmas tree on your paper.
(2) Use foil tape to create a path from the LED's negative side to one side of the battery.
(3) Bend a corner of the paper to bring the foil tape into contact with the other side of the battery.
(4) Test your LED light. Once it lights up, stick it on the tree.
(5) Watch as your Christmas tree craft becomes a glowing beacon of festive joy!

⭕ SCIENCE EXPLAINED: 
This simple circuit uses a coin cell battery to power the LED. When the foil tape connects the LED to the battery, it completes the circuit, allowing electricity to flow and light up the LED. It's a fun, hands-on way to learn about basic electronics and circuits!

videos.title: Mixing COKE and MILK | Coca Cola VS Milk Chemical Reaction Experiment
videos.description:
Ever wondered what happens when you mix Coca Cola with milk? Join us in this fascinating science experiment as we explore the chemical reaction between Coke and milk! 🥤🥛 #ScienceExperiment #CokeAndMilk

Watch the mixture go through a reaction that creates a bizarre and intriguing effect! Perfect for science enthusiasts and the curious-minded of all ages!

Don’t miss out on the reaction!
   - 00:00 Introduction
   - 00:05 Testing how much milk we need
   - 02:27 The Mixing Begins
   - 03:01 24 hours later

Science Behind
The Coca-Cola has a special chemical in it called phosphoric acid. This acid reacts with the calcium that is naturally found in the milk. When the acid and calcium mix together, they create a new substance that looks like little white clumps or chunks.
These white clumps are actually the milk proteins that have been changed by the acid in the Coca-Cola. The reaction causes the milk proteins to stick together and form this solid, precipitate material that sinks to the bottom of the glass.
The two liquids that we started with have now turned into something completely different! The Coca-Cola and milk no longer look the same, and you can see the reaction happening right before your eyes.

Isn't that cool? It just goes to show that when you mix certain things together, you can get some really surprising and interesting results! Let me know if you have any other questions about this Coca-Cola and milk experiment in the comments below.

Remember, always explore science with safety first. Grab your safety goggles and let's get experimenting!
